name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Mr Carlos Coelho, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the public procurement strategy package (2017/2278(INI) (A8-0229/2018).

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner Bienkowska, four years have passed on the reform of public procurement legislation. It is time to take stock of their implementation by the Member States. What is going well and going wrong in the application of European rules. We agree that, for the proper functioning of the internal market, it is crucial to define a comprehensive and strategic policy framework for public procurement that promotes growth, jobs and innovation. In our economy, public procurement represents a substantial part of public investment. More than 2 billion euros a year. This means that 250,000 public authorities use about 14% of the Union's GDP to purchase services, works and supplies through public procurement. We know that the provision of high-quality public services depends to a large extent on modern, efficient and transparent procurement processes. The report under discussion today responds precisely to this need. We agree with the European Commission's strategy of proposing a package of non-legislative measures, two communications and a recommendation on the professionalisation of public procurement. We don't need more laws, but a good implementation of the laws we have. That is why we have a number of recommendations which the Internal Market Committee wants to see implemented. Ladies and gentlemen, the directives adopted in 2014 are not only an instrument for regulating the public procurement of goods, services and works. They should contribute to Member States promoting policies on innovation, green economy and circular, sustainable and inclusive growth. We regret, however, the disappointing pace at which many Member States have transposed the Directives, even leading to infringement procedures, and we are aware that many of the criticisms point to a protectionist nature, the difficult access and understanding for small and medium-sized enterprises, the comparatory and the little transparency and the fact that the only award criterion appears to be the lowest price , rather than, for example, strategic social and environmental criteria for communities. My report therefore proposes, among other measures, that, where possible, and if justified, quality criteria be adopted in place of the lowest price criterion, paragraphs 12 and 13. The participation of small and medium-sized enterprises in public procurement is supported by, for example, stimulating batch division, paragraph 38. Transparency instruments such as contract registers, paragraphs 29, 33 and 41, are introduced. Invest and accelerate digitization at all stages of the procurement process, paragraphs 26 to 33, and promote innovation, paragraphs 4, 23 and 24. National procurement strategies, systematic analysis of data and professionalization plans for agents dealing with public procurement, paragraphs 53 to 57 should be developed. Unfair competition is being fought in cross-border procurement procedures and improving access to public procurement markets in third countries, paragraphs 45 to 49. High standards of ethics and deontology are applied at all stages of the process, paragraphs 15 and 20. In conclusion, Mr President, I sincerely thank the shadow rapporteurs who have worked so closely on this report and for the opinions drawn up by the ENVI and INTRA committees. I believe that we have come to a good report, which sets out the right approach to efficient, effective and competitive public procurement, which responds to the challenges facing the sector today and makes a strategic contribution to achieving objectives such as innovation, social inclusion and economic and environmental sustainability.  I count on the support of all colleagues for the final adoption of this report which promotes the smooth functioning of the single market, business growth and employment and protects the interests of citizens. Ensuring that taxpayers' money is spent efficiently and effectively is in the common interest and is a legitimate requirement of our citizens.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members very much for the discussion on this subject.  Public procurement is a very important subject. You have heard the data and you have heard the numbers, but at the same time, besides the data and the numbers, this is a powerful tool which can help carry out policy. We are not using the full potential of public procurement at the moment. Taxpayers are often still not getting the best value for money and do not see results that provide them with the best public services.  That’s why we decided last year – almost a year ago, in November last year – to adopt a public procurement package because we feel that we need a major shift in the culture of public procurement (PP). But at the same time it is also important, as you have heard, that this package is not new legislation. It is made up of voluntary measures, recommendations, suggestions, some new ideas and best practices. It calls for a wide partnership, but also for political ownership of this topic. The package is our attempt to jointly steer the political discussion on PP, to identify priorities and to offer tools for implementing them. We also underlined the role that public procurement can play in responding to European competitiveness and to societal environmental innovation challenges because we know that, for example, it can encourage energy and resource efficiency investment. It can foster innovation and facilitate social inclusion.  We specifically addressed the importance of selecting the most economically advantageous tenders based on a cost effectiveness approach to get the best value for public money for all our citizens, but – as was said before – the most economically advantageous is not always the cheapest. It can never be underlined and repeated enough that EU law does not require the lowest price as the only award criteria. The package shows how the possibilities offered by the Public Procurement Directives can be used to support wider EU policy objectives. It contains practical measures and guidance along with implementation support from the Commission. So we recommend some actions and offer assistance at the same time.  We organised the package around six priorities. Let me briefly list them. The first one is ensuring wider use of innovative, green and social procurement, then professionalising public buyers – there we need the right competencies and skills of the people who are dealing with this topic – increasing access to procurement markets for SMEs and all EU businesses, though of course SMEs are at the centre of our interest, improving transparency and integrity, delivering better data, boosting the digital transformation of procurement, using technologies to simplify and to reorganise procedures, and cooperating more between authorities at different levels, to procure together. In March the Council endorsed the package and underlined its importance for European competitiveness. In February we also discussed this package in the Ecofin Council to show the importance of good procurement for public budgets. We definitely know that improving the way procurement is carried out and focusing on the professionalisation of public buyers can really generate important savings in Member States’ budgets.  The Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions have also adopted their opinions so I am very glad that today Parliament will complete this interinstitutional cycle and adopt the own initiative report. I appreciate that this has been done after a thorough debate with contributions from many of you, under the really valuable leadership of Mr Coelho, together with the shadow rapporteurs. You have prepared a good report, which largely supports the Commission’s proposed approach, while at the same time giving us food for thought for the future. I am also happy to see that there is a large degree of consensus within Parliament and substantial agreement with the Commission’s view on some specific issues.  I will mention just three or four of them. First SMEs, as was underlined before. I would caution against too much pessimism. There is not a big share of SMEs participating in the public procurement market, and as the directive has only been recently transposed I think it will take some time before the simplification really takes effect. We have launched a recent study to identify the possible remaining barriers to SME participation in procurement.  The second point is on quality criteria – what else? – and strategic procurement. Here the situation varies enormously between the Member States. In many there is still a lot of scope to increase the use of quality criteria. We believe that spreading the word that clarifying the lowest price is not mandatory at all, and obtaining high—level commitment to that principle is extremely important. I also think that we should make it easier to apply green, innovative and social procurement. That’s why we are updating existing guidance and compiling best practices to assist authorities incurring tenders. I would also like to stress that we fully share the views of the report when pointing at the huge benefits that digitisation of procurement could bring. The last point is on the professionalisation of public services, first through more cooperation and exchange of good practices. On this point I couldn’t agree more. We have launched an e—competence centre and a web page bringing together all guidance and good practice from different Member States. We are developing a European competence framework for public buyers to make sure that the skills competences they require are clearly identified.  These are the main points. Thank you very much for taking this subject on board.

name: Reimer BÖGE
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Indeed, the public dimension of public procurement is often mentioned or analysed only casually. But that would be a mistake. Indeed, we are still in a situation today where public procurement markets in third countries are often de jure and de facto closed for competitors from the European Union. We must press for better access here. The Commissioner said: yes, the challenges and problems for SMEs in particular when it comes to the international dimension must be taken seriously and taken seriously. A key problem on the road to better market access is, on the one hand, multilateral agreements, and above all the government procurement agreement. However, regardless of this, better market access as the core interest of the European Union remains an important element of our bilateral trade talks. And the CETA agreement, as well as the EPA with Japan, are actually successful examples of this, which should continue to be included as pilot projects, as an important element for further negotiations. The final point is that the international dimension of public procurement in particular has the potential to make an important contribution as a growth driver for more growth and new jobs in Europe.

And it is a good moment for me to point out that the thresholds that we have in the European Union, which are also set in Germany, are not set by the European Union, but are derived from the Global Procurement Agreement, and should therefore be made clear that the European economy, unlike some Presidents of the United States of America, does not see Europe first as the centre of attention. , but wants to ensure a certain openness of the markets, so that our companies in other markets in particular can hope for the same openness. In the long term, Commissioner, they should not only be able to hope for this, but we must put even more pressure on them to ensure that other countries actually open up their markets as much as we have opened up our markets. The report by Mr Coelho, which I very much welcome, clearly shows, in my view, that there is really no reason in the Member States that 55% of contracts are still awarded on the basis of the lowest price alone, because with the Procurement Directive and the 2014 reform, we are actually offering quite a lot of opportunities for the contracting authorities, at whatever state level. , have created to make the best offer in the end eligible. That is why I urge all contracting authorities – not only in Germany, but throughout Europe – to think carefully about the conditions that will be included in the call for tenders in order to actually get the best offer in the end and not to complain afterwards that the cheapest offer has been taken again and that certain legal difficulties arise in the aftermath. I believe, Commissioner – as you rightly pointed out – that with digitisation in the area of public procurement law – and Portugal is a shining example here – we can still create a great deal of flexibility and transparency. This should still be of considerable help to all European companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, with the revision of the 2014 public procurement regulatory framework, Europe has had good legislation, the potential of which has not yet been fully exploited by most Member States.  The report, for which I thank Mr Coelho and our rapporteur Marc Tarabella, provides a comprehensive overview of the state of transposition and implementation of these rules, but also of the most urgent issues to be addressed at European and national level.  I would like to focus on three points, the first: we must continue with the application of quality criteria in the award of contracts. All too often, unfair competition, a lack of attention to sustainability, social inclusion and disability are hidden behind a low price.  Secondly, we must take note of the fact that European SMEs and social economy companies only win 45% of the value of contracts, which is clearly at odds with their real weight in the economy. Concrete measures will have to be taken on this issue, including, for example, compulsory batching, combined with better assistance and training for small and medium-sized enterprises.  Thirdly, in parallel with the construction of the digital single market, we must also change the pace of the process of digitising public procurement. We need simplified procedures, less bureaucracy and more transparency. Finally, I would also like to mention the issue of reciprocity in the field of international public procurement. The opening up of our public markets must not make us forget how difficult, if not impossible, it is for European bidders to enter third-country markets. This is an intolerable imbalance which the Commission and the Member States must quickly remedy, for example through the approval of the so-called instrument for international procurement, which is still hostage to internal vetoes in the Council.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Coelho and the shadow rapporteurs for their smooth and good work. The potential of public procurement is obviously enormous. 250 000 public authorities in the Union spend around 14% every year of our GDP – nearly EUR 2 000 billion each year on purchasing services, work and supplies – and still, this enormous potential is not fully achieved. There are three reasons for that. Firstly, because Member States have been very late in transposing the 2014 directives on public procurement – so late that the Commission had to initiate infringement procedures against some of them, and, unfortunately, I do suspect they will again be late transposing for the next round of deadlines, notably regarding e—procurement.  Secondly, Member States’ authorities on a national, regional and local level are not using public procurement strategically. That’s why I urge them to not consider public procurement as an administrative burden, but a way to promote a smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, to force innovation to help SMEs to gain new markets, create new jobs.  Thirdly, because the practitioners of public procurement need further education. Those directives are indeed complicated and Member States should therefore organise training in order to get it right in public procurement and open university courses to develop public procurement studies and public procurement law.  That’s why I welcome all the action proposed here, all the strategies taken by the Commission, and I wish to remind everybody that an effective public procurement will lead to taxpayers’ money being better spent in the Union.

name: Tim AKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, there needs to be a new way to look at procurement to make sure taxpayers’ money stays within the local area, creating jobs and ensuring local investment. Traditional rules meant big business swooped in and took huge local government contracts. The legal complications and expense in placing tender bids has squeezed out local competition. In my own borough of Thurrock in South Essex, residents were surprised to see the new gas maintenance provider had its head office in Liverpool. It’s as if there are no good quality local providers anymore, and big businesses consume all and leave nothing in their wake.  Procurement rules need to change to stop this, and Preston Council is showing just how to do it. It is prioritising contracts based on localism and keeping money in the local economy. Research from the Federation of Small Businesses has shown that, for every pound spent with a small or medium sized firm, 63 pence is respent locally – that drops to 40 pence or less with a large or multinational company.  Before Preston changed the way it looked at procurement, only one pound in twenty stayed in Preston. Surely we would be better off with local solutions to contracts and tendering wherever possible. From my own experience as a councillor, we would be better off with local maintenance contracts: people who live in the same community they look after making repairs.  The government may well say that austerity is over, but there are choppy waters ahead. Councils can prepare for this now by thinking differently about procurement, keeping money local in dividing up contracts to ensure money stays with local firms, and small businesses can help prepare for uncertain times ahead.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

text: blue-card answer. – Yes, that’s a very good point, and what you see is a race to the bottom in contracts. But the experience in Preston is that if they keep contracts local and give to small and local businesses, the money is respent and reinvested, and local people are employed, which in the medium term will reduce expenditure at local government level. So I quite agree; I think it’s time that the rules were changed to keep money as local as possible to help the local economy.

text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, transparency and respect for a certain ethics in public procurement are natural objectives, common sense, which did not wait for this text to be expressed, but which nevertheless requires logical support from us.  However, the text is not limited to these objectives. These requirements of transparency and honesty are associated with other, much less obvious provisions. The systematic and non-negotiable opening of public procurement to third countries poses real problems of sovereignty and independence. National governments must be able to independently develop the criteria for the choice of companies to win these contracts.  This fundamental difference marks a major divide between the ultra-liberals who manage the European Union and the nationals who want to protect their country. For us, economic, social and environmental objectives are sincere goals that you constantly use for the benefit of your project without borders. Localism and the national preference for public procurement, to the extent of capacity, are strategic interests for us. This national preference, we assume, is why we will vote against this text.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to single out one point from Mr Coelho's excellent report, which I think is very important. The report notes that the number of tenders with only one bid increased from 14% to 29% between 2006 and 2016. So, to put it another way, one third of all tenders result in a provider being available. I find that very, very alarming as a figure, frankly. And when you consider why, you have to take note of the fact that it may also be too much effort for SMEs and for small and medium-sized enterprises to participate in tenders. We have now built a new school in my home community. Here, too, we were above the threshold of five million. In other words, we advertised throughout Europe and we had only one provider. And I can tell you that the disillusionment with the public authorities is, of course, immense. You advertise across Europe, a huge effort without end, and then one or from the region applies for two. One wonders: do we have to put everything out to tender throughout Europe? What do I mean by that? On the one hand, I would like to stress that public procurement must also take into account the interests of public authorities and the burden. And I would be very pleased if we – not now, not in the near future, but at the next revision of the rules on public procurement – we would also discuss the thresholds again. I think the instrument is very good. We need transparency. We must allow fair competition in public tenders. But it is not acceptable that a third of all tenders should ultimately be completely ineffective. We need to think about why. I believe that there is still a need to correct there, particularly in the construction sector, because it does not make sense to travel from Portugal or Cyprus or elsewhere for school construction in my home region of Bavaria. So I just ask you to take that with me for the next revision.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, public procurement, especially in some Member States, is a chronic wound and a source of corruption. Unfortunately, however, there have been cases in which European institutions have not had the best conduct. It is legitimate to find new methods of awarding public contracts and optimising existing ones, always with a view to greater transparency, greater efficiency and less bureaucracy, in the public interest.  However, I personally believe that the lower price should continue to play an important role in the award of contracts, while introducing new criteria. In any case, the sovereignty of the Member States, which must have the final say in any public contract, should not be infringed. At the same time, however, competitions must be closely monitored so as not to repeat the phenomena of widespread corruption, as has been observed in many countries of the Union. The main aim must first and for all be to combat such phenomena. We can no longer allow some to get rich at the expense of the citizens.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is very good that we have a Parliament's own-initiative report on this subject, it is very good that we are reviewing the legislative package on public procurement. Moreover, in 2014, when the directive was amended, I had my grievances and, lo and behold, it turned out that I was right. Firstly, the 2014 directive, in my view, is extremely general, evisionable and allows there to be a very large difference in national public procurement legislation in the Member States. And now we are dealing with some very big things and I do not know, Commissioner, how we can solve them with the new package. For example, appeals. The challenges greatly prolong the spending of the money that we are supposed to spend in order to have an immediate effect of that investment. There is no very clear definition - who can and when to appeal, as we define the person concerned, because a boutique cannot challenge an auction for a road infrastructure.  Then the lowest price - discussed here - does not apply and the Commission has done this analysis: over sixty per cent of purchases are not at the lowest price. And there's another problem: research - especially medical research. In my view, purchases for medical research should be excluded.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I was indeed the rapporteur for the opinion in the ENVI Committee. The chairman of the committee appears officially, but in reality I have made the report. In my report, I focused in particular on the procurement of food for public tasks, for example for canteens, in kindergartens, in schools or even in hospitals. I think that it is precisely there that customers and, above all, the parents of pupils want local food, for example, and that it is sometimes somewhat absurd for public administrations to be forced to buy products that are carved from afar through public tenders. I have every sympathy for the European internal market. I think it is good and reasonable. However, I also think that, in such cases, we must also use common sense and respond to the desire of public administrations and the desire of customers, users of these public canteens for local food. That is why I believe that we must find a solution to public tenders, so that it is precisely in this area that contracting entities have the chance to buy local food.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, I agree with much of what has been said this morning in the debate about the need to make procurement processes more accessible to SMEs, and indeed charities and local voluntary organisations as well, but the issue I want to highlight specifically is the scandal that is modern slavery.  Cases of modern slavery are increasing across the European Union. In my own country, 136 000 people are estimated to have been victims of modern slavery in 2017. It would be a scandal if modern slavery is being propped up and supported by the spending of public money through procurement and the supply chains of organisations winning public contracts.  So I endorse – and I hope this Parliament can endorse this morning – action to tackle modern slavery through procurement. One specific example is the Co—operative Party’s Charter Against Modern Slavery, which local and public authorities are signing in the UK. When it comes to modern slavery in public procurement, there can be nowhere to hide.

name: Rupert MATTHEWS
text: – Mr President, thank you for calling me to speak on this important issue. When it comes to government procurement, big is convenient. Big companies and big contracts are beloved by far too many who award government contracts. But small is beautiful. Small companies can be more effective, more efficient and very often cheaper than their large rivals.  Unfortunately, however, smaller companies are very often excluded from tendering for contracts, and I’m very pleased to be supporting this report, which seeks to address that.  But we need to go further. In my region, smaller companies suffer very often from late payments, from convoluted bureaucracy, from all sorts of bureaucratic hoops that they have to jump through in order to get the contracts and in order to be paid after they have done the work.  Small is beautiful. Small companies offer a good deal to government, a good deal for local workers. We must do more to encourage them.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, each State concludes contracts with various companies and domestic and foreign companies for remuneration. These contracts play an important role in the development of the State's economy, because they are usually made in sectors of great strategic importance, such as heavy industry, public works, construction, energy, telecommunications and others. With these conventions, therefore, the State is trying to promote its economic – and not only – policy, as long as it has not delegated all its productive resources to foreigners, as the last governments in Greece have done because of the implementation of the Memorandums.  In any event, in order for this effort to succeed, what is important is that third-country markets should also be accessible. These countries have, because of protectionism, created difficulties in accessing and offerings from European companies. That is why, and in order to strike a balance between fair competition measures, European countries should take advantage of the directives given by the reform of the legislative framework for contracts.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Public procurement and the law governing them are an extremely important element of the proper functioning not only at national level, but above all among local and regional authorities and bodies. I am therefore pleased that the Commission has taken the initiative to develop a strategy that focuses on six clear priorities. Public procurement procedures must, above all, be transparent and understandable, and I therefore support the call for their maximum possible simplification. The great potential in this direction lies in the use of new technologies to create so-called e-procurement, holistically implemented online. I would also like to stress the importance of the criteria for settling tenders being enriched with indicators other than just the lowest price. Contracting institutions must pay attention to the quality and sustainability of projects.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, 250,000 public bodies award public contracts for works, for supplies, for services. The cost is EUR 2 trillion, or 14% of GDP. It is understood that these are huge, significant amounts of taxpayers and it has been shown that there have been too many scandals in the area of public procurement.  At the same time, public procurement could support growth, create jobs, contribute to strengthening the state's own strategy, taking into account social and environmental criteria. We see that small and medium-sized enterprises have only taken 45% of the assignments, while 55% of the assignments have been made on the basis of the principle of low price, i.e. the reduction, which does not mean that there is always a guarantee that the projects are efficient.  At the same time, internationalisation creates problems in the European Union, as it opens up the market, as was the case with the CETA and TTIR agreements, while other third countries keep their own markets closed. So let us look at certain elements, whether locality or national preference, as elements of enhancing the competitiveness of European businesses.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will admit that I am in favour of reducing the amount of money spent by public entities in public procurement, but I am even more opposed to public bodies doing business, especially local authorities. I have the impression that, recently, this second element is unfortunately eerily eerily controlling the various institutions and should be subject to special monitoring. On the other hand, I would like to draw attention to two elements, wanting to commend my colleague Carlos Coelho, because he has done, in my opinion, a good job. We have two elements that determine the quality of the tender. On the one hand, legislation, namely the external financial framework, but also the precision of the contract itself, on the other. It seems to me that recently, on the basis of the observations of many different tendering procedures, especially the latter element leaves much to be desired. And that is what I am paying attention to at the end of my speech.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, even from this discussion it is clear how important this subject is. I want to reiterate that the reason we decided to adopt this packet is not because we have bad legislation. The legislation is new, the legislation is fresh, and we think this is good legislation. What is bad is the implementation. This is in response to those of you who are saying that there is not enough flexibility: the legislation gives a lot of flexibility and room to manoeuver. Of course, laws must be obeyed, but it gives quite a lot of room for manoeuver, for example, for social services, from the possibility of exclusion via a light regime to integration of all of the social criteria in tendering. For this specific topic, we are preparing some guidelines on social public procurement to help Member States.  We also share with you the opinion that the digitisation of public procurement is extremely important. On the one hand, it will substantially improve transparency, for example, regarding late payments. On the other hand, we see in the Member States that have implemented e—procurement, that it has increased the participation of small and medium-sized enterprises in the process. Only a few Member States have introduced such an option, but the Commission advocates for the full cycle of public procurement.  Concerning the local level. Many of you mentioned this, and I fully understand it. I had a lot of personal experience with public procurement. Let me tell you, it is not European legislation that is a huge burden for them. The burden is the gold-plating: these are additional things added to the legislation during the transposition process. This is a problem. This is a serious problem everywhere in Europe, and that’s why we decided that this is not the moment for thinking about any changes in the legislation. But in this partnership that we want to create, this exchange of views and guidance, it’s sometimes fear that really stops people from taking the right decision. They just don’t know, they do not have enough skills and they just don’t know how to do it.  Some of you mentioned the late transposition of the directive: the largest deficit in such statistics that we have is in Germany, because the state of transposition is very late. Therefore, we do not have statistics on how it works on the ground.  Let me just add that since the adoption, we have implemented an ex—ante tool for large investment projects. This has already launched a very concrete service to help public buyers to apply the rules and to avoid problems while tendering for really big sums on infrastructure projects. We have disseminated several hundred examples of good practices on professionalisation. We have published our innovation guidance document, but as I said, the next one will be on the social topic and social public procurement.  I’m strongly committed, both to the subject and to the topic, and I am strongly committed to maintaining this discussion with you, because this topic is really worthwhile.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank Commissioner Bienkowska for the references she made and what she said. Start by stressing what she has mentioned now. We are dealing with a clear case in which Europe has done well, where we approve our legislative framework in time and where the problems result from the slow and sometimes wrong transposition of legislation by the Member States. We can't ask ourselves for more. We have to ask the Member States not to undermine what we have been able to do at European level. I would like to thank all my colleagues for their contributions and to underline three points: firstly, I think there is a great consensus on the great objectives of this initiative, the idea that, with this instrument, we will promote more transparency and fight corruption, we will ensure fair competition and we will have instruments to pursue objectives of innovation, ecological economy and circular and sustainable and inclusive growth , the idea that we also have to have social criteria here.  The second idea, the concern for small and medium-sized enterprises. I believe that most of the interventions we have heard this morning, and thirdly and lastly, have been the idea of digitisation, not only as a tool for simplifying processes, but also for ensuring better transparency. Mr President, I believe that this is everyone's concern, to ensure that taxpayers' money is well spent, it is a requirement that all our citizens make and I hope that in today's vote there will be a clear signal from the European Parliament around the recommendations we propose.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 4 October 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The 2014 Directives not only reviewed the Union's public procurement legal framework, but also modernised the rights responsible for them. This broad reform was intended directly to implement the Europe 2020 strategy and to make a significant contribution to the growth and competitiveness of the European Union. The directives were, inter alia, a requirement for the digitisation of public procurement.  Four years after the formal adoption of the directives, there is no full insight into how the directives have been transposed and how they are implemented in individual EU countries. In many Member States, there have been significant delays in transposition, forcing the Commission to initiate infringement proceedings.  An important step in this report is the introduction of a set of soft measures to increase the effectiveness of the implementation of public procurement rules in the Member States and to speed up national reforms. Nevertheless, the European Parliament reserves the right to request the European Commission at any time to propose legislative measures to improve the public procurement framework.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – The public procurement system must be transparent and fair. It is an important tool that helps to address public policy issues such as reducing social exclusion, job creation, improving environmental sustainability The effective conduct of public procurement must be ensured across the EU. It is essential that measures to promote the effectiveness of public procurement are used properly. The efficiency of public procurement administrations must be improved. The procurement procedure itself must be clear, without creating unnecessary administrative burdens. Particular attention needs to be paid to SMEs. They must be given appropriate access to tender. I also believe that there is a need to promote faster digitisation, which in turn would contribute to increasing transparency, and to prevent fraud and corruption in the procurement process.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. – The European Union spends up to EUR 2 trillion a year on public works, service and goods procurement. This is a huge amount of taxpayers' money, which is why procurement should be carried out as efficiently, ethically and transparently as possible. I welcome the fact that facilitating access to the procurement market is one of the Commission's priorities in public procurement. I think it is very important that tenders are carried out in such a way that small and medium-sized enterprises can also participate in them. It is not right if tenders are tailored to suit only certain companies. The calls mentioned in the report, for example, for the division of public contracts into parts and the turnover threshold, are worth supporting in order to provide fair conditions of competition for smaller operators as well. In addition to supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, public procurement can promote, for example, environmental friendliness and the circular economy, innovation and social objectives, such as better care for older people and people with disabilities. I am concerned about the fact that competition in public procurement in the Union has deteriorated in recent years. In some Member States, a large proportion of tenders are tenders where only one tender is received. Such a situation cannot guarantee the best possible services and procurement at the best possible price.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – Do public procurement, where the only criterion is the lowest price, really stimulate the economy, reduce social exclusion, be environmentally sustainable and help innovation emerge? Is there sufficient transparency and simplicity for public procurement in the Member States of the European Union, of course, also in Lithuania? Do small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) receive sufficient public attention, given their access to public procurement? Public procurement is an important part of the market and, in order to implement the principles of the social market, we should strive for public procurement to be socially responsible. I agree that the European Parliament, at least in the form of a resolution, would call on the Member States to see public procurement as an opportunity to promote a sustainable, socially responsible economy, to open up pathways for innovation, to enable growth and to grow in a competitive environment for SMEs. The lowest price and the most economically advantageous tender do not always coincide. It is indeed important to take into account the whole life cycle of products, environmental requirements, social aspects. The digitalisation aspect of public procurement is also very relevant, and the introduction of innovative technologies would help to address language barriers and promote cross-border public procurement.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the deterioration of media freedom in Belarus, in particular in the case of Charter 97 (2018/2861(RSP)).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, I cautiously welcomed the 2016 decision to ease some of the restrictive measures against Belarusian officials as part of an EU broader strategy of engagement with that isolated country. But now, given the annexation of Crimea by Russia and its offensive in the east of Ukraine, there is a belief that Lukashenko, the President of Belarus, may have somehow welcomed warmer relations with the European Union as a counterweight to Russia’s dominance of the country, fearing that he too could go the way of President Yanukovych of Ukraine. Such an approach, it was hoped, might yield results in terms of greater freedom and democratic and human rights within Belarus and opening up the country to the west.  As the case of the website Charter 97 however illustrates, such thinking was far too optimistic. As our resolution today makes clear, journalists are being targeted by police in a systematic and deliberate policy of harassment and intimidation. Death threats to the editor—in—chief, Natalya Radina, being a particularly concerning example. Hopes of President Lukashenko changing his stripes were perhaps premature, but we can remain certain that the continued support for organisations such as Charter 97 will be vital to ensuring, one day, a democratic, free and successful Belarus in the future.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: Author. – Mr President, the ordinary resolution on the situation of democratic rights in Belarus. Today we are talking about freedom of the press, that is, the captivity of the press and the continuing persecution of free people in Belarus.  The Internet is now being taken – all internet commentators will be registered and their data transferred to the KGB. There are no limits to the fantasy and activity of this law firm. We know that from history.  I want to make it very clear. Firstly, it is not enough for charter 97 to voice our oral support over and over again.  The Commission and the External Action Service must make the blocking of the portal close to an end. The portal needs specific financial support and must come from the European Union.  Secondly, the political monster Lukashenko is creating a nuclear monster for himself, the Astravo nuclear power plant. The fundamental right of the people of Belarus and europe as a whole, the right to security, will be mentioned. The European Union's action must be based on strict conditions and clear requirements, not on attempts to intervene. The Commission and the External Action Service must stop acting naïvely. It is quite ignored that Minsk does not try to even imitate change. I call for the negotiations on partnership priorities to be terminated and for serious action to be taken.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Author. – Mr President, indeed, today's Belarus is an eloquent example of how the restraint of a free press and human rights violations pose a direct threat to the security of the country, the region and the continent as a whole. After surviving one of the worst nuclear disasters in human history, Belarus has recently embarked on a nuclear accident, the consequences of which could be far more severe than the Chernobyl accident. By restricting civil society and independent media, such as charter 97, Belarus has allowed the Putin regime of Russia to build a nuclear scare at the Borders of the European Union. Even the Soviets froze construction projects of this type of reactor in Belarus in the wake of the Chernobyl accident. The construction of the Astravo nuclear power plant is already visible from the territory of Lithuania. I am constantly getting questions from citizens – what is the European Union doing to ensure nuclear security? I would like to ask the Commission: how will the results of the European Union stress tests at the nuclear power plant in Astravo be guaranteed? Are millions of European Taxpayers travelling to Belarus not simply supporting the nuclear construction of Astravo, including the associated press regimes?

name: Clare MOODY
text: author. – Mr President, a free and independent press is a fundamental European value, and it must be an essential part of the EU’s relationship with Belarus. Charter 97 provides a clear example of where our values are being undermined. Their news website was blocked in Belarus, and more recently in Russia, in an attempt to stamp out informed public debate. Other websites and social media are also being tracked, preventing anonymity in order to prevent free speech.  This highlights a worrying trend of a wider clampdown on civil society in an already oppressive environment. Belarus is acting against free association too, most worryingly with the case against independent trade unionists. In 2016, the EU lifted most sanctions that were in place against Belarusian officials and companies in a spirit of engagement, hoping that better relations would lead to better fundamental freedoms. It is now clear that this is not working. The case of Charter 97 and that of the trade unionists most recently make this failure clear.  Now is the time for action. The EEAS needs to get funding in place for organisations such as Charter 97 and Belsat-TV, which provide independent broadcasting. This funding needs to be direct and it needs to be swift. The EU’s support for Belarus must have conditions and there must be consequences for not meeting those conditions. Harassment, death threats and the imprisonment of journalists, human rights defenders, trade unionists and others are surely the sort of violations that should cost Belarus its EU financial support.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Mr President, in the face of this statement we are once again faced with the double measuring stick or the double standard of this House. The Resolution adequately underlines the repression in Belarus and that this repression hinders any closer relationship with the European Union and wider participation in the Eastern Partnership. However, between 2014 and 2017 the European Union's assistance package to Belarus under the European Neighbourhood Instrument amounted to EUR 91.5 million. The agreement focuses in particular on human mobility — what a coincidence — and seeks to outsource border control in the European Union to reduce migration flows by supporting, for example, the development of migrant detention centres. In other words, we recognize that human rights are being violated in Belarus but we close our eyes and pay them, and we pay a lot of money for that state we say violates human rights to make us border police. All very coherent, ladies and gentlemen. We must remember that Belarus lacks an asylum system and has handed over people seeking international protection to countries where they were at real risk of persecution. Belarus is another example of how everything is worth in order to reduce the Union's migration flows. It is truly alarming how many political groups in this House have that have refused to include this circumstance in the Resolution.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Author. – Mr President, free media and independent journalists. They're lukeshenko's arch-enemies. Journalists of independent media are the target of a relentless process of intimidation. The Charter 97 information web portal has been blocked for almost a year. In 2010, its co-founder was assassinated, charter expelled from Belarus and broadcasts from Poland since 2011. Blocking her site is economically crushing her. In August this year, there was a wave of arrests and foreclosures in several newsrooms. Journalists face criminal charges and face prison sentences. Last year, more than 100 journalists were arrested. Almost two years ago, we abolished restrictive measures against Belarus. The Belarusian side benefits from European money. I therefore appeal to the conditionality of our cooperation, to respect for the fundamental rights and freedoms of belarusian citizens. Lukashenko shows us that instead of democratization, he tightens the screws and persecutes those who seek to freely inform fellow citizens about what is happening in the country. Let's not trust dictators, ladies and gentlemen. The web portal Charter 97 was founded on the basis of the Belarusian movement Charter 97, a movement inspired by The Czechoslovak Charter 77. Another important reason, ladies and gentlemen, is why I feel, why, as a Czech, I feel obliged to fight human rights violations in Belarus. Freedom is indivisible. Belarusian freedom is also our freedom.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As Chairman of the Delegation for Relations with Belarus, I should ensure the completeness of this type of opinion, the completeness of the discussions, and therefore I will not go back to the speech of my colleague štětina or colleague Tannock or colleague Auštrevičius. I will add to my opinion, to your speech one very important element. Cultural element. There is no doubt that Belarus could be proud of its artists, of its work, of its folk culture. After all, they also have a Nobel Prize in Literature. The theatre, on the other hand, is being harassed. In this case, I want to say exactly about the Belarusian free theatre, which is being bullied in many ways. Artists are harassed, professors are harassed, who help this theater, but even the audience. I draw attention to this, because I want the opinion that comes out of the European Parliament to be truly complete, complete and take into account not only the fate, the problems of charter'97 or Belsat, but also the artists themselves.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the EU must take action on Belarus. The passivity of the Commission and the European External Action Service has now emboldened Lukashenko’s government. The human rights situation, in particular when it comes to press freedom, is deteriorating quickly, and the treatment of political prisoners is horrific in a country where the death penalty remains a shameful option.  The case of human rights defender Mikhail Zhamchuzhny is particularly horrific. He has been kept in solitary confinement for most of the time since the last week of July and this, ladies and gentlemen, is in Europe. Dmitry Bobryk, a journalist arrested in August in a vicious attack on press freedom, has reported that – whilst in detention – he was forced to sign a cooperation agreement with the KGB, and the case of Charter 97, as already described, is very concerning. I have worked with that organisation over the past few months, and they feel totally betrayed by the EU. I therefore urge Commissioner Hahn and the High Representative to take action and demand improvements in Belarus’ human rights record.

name: Marek JUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Belarus is an important nation close to us, a country bordering three, that is, more than a tenth of the countries of the European Union. This nation today is working on its memory, fighting for its memory.  In Kuropaty near Minsk, according to estimates of polish-British historian Norman Davies, a quarter of a million people were murdered. Fortunately, this place began to be surrounded by respect and memory. Today he is in danger of being desaralized. Social protests continue. Archbishop Tadeusz Kondrusiewicz, Metropolitan of Minsk-Mogilev, said that the memory of the victims of the Partridge, respect for this cemetery (on which there are few crosses, because most of the victims are unknown) is a test of humanity, a test of consciousness of this nation.  I appeal to the Belarusian authorities: prevent the desacracies of this place, join in cultivating the memory of this great tragedy of humanity, which should unite us all. It is time to condemn all the crimes of communism!

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the situation of the press in Belarus has continued to worsen. Belarus now ranks 155 out of 180 in the World Press Freedom Index. Harassment, intimidation, threats now form part of the daily life of independent journalists in Belarus. In early August 2018, Belarusian authorities carried out raids in the newsroom of the independent Belarusian outlets Tut.by and BelaPAN. At the same time, the government recently extended its control over media outlets by compelling everybody to register with the authorities before even being able to publish. This is beyond what anybody even in this Chamber could imagine. Therefore, Belarusian authorities have to lift the ban of the Charter 97 and all the other independent media and I ask this Chamber to continue our support to the Belarus NGOs. We owe it to the citizens of Belarus to defend their freedom of expression.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Belarus is often regarded as the last dictatorship in Europe, the only European country not to be in the Council of Europe. The death penalty is still rife. No elections have been deemed to meet international standards since 2001. Lukashenko was re-elected in 2015 with 83.5% of the vote.  So, yes, freedom of expression is a decoy: the closure of Charter 97 is just one example. However, the European Union is becoming more and more complacent. We are even negotiating a visa liberalisation agreement. What for? Out of naivety? No. In an attempt to reproduce a Ukrainian-like scenario? Perhaps, but also because Belarus is a european Union policeman. The bulk of the $91 million under the Neighbourhood Instrument is spent not on mobility, but on closing borders, for the greater interest of the Polish government.  Hundreds of people from Chechnya, Tajikistan and even Syria were stranded in Brest, near the Belarusian border. Poland refused to consider their asylum applications and some were sent back, including to Russia. It's a big deal! Poland is more complacent with Ukrainian workers and has a good game of denouncing migration invasions coming from the South, refusing to participate in any European solidarity.  We turn a blind eye to what is happening at this border and proceed with refoulements to countries where human rights violations are denounced: total inconsistency! Two weights, two measures, as always, depending on the interest of the Member States.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, society is as free as its media is. I am very glad that the European Parliament agrees on the promotion of free media. Journalists in Belarus are experiencing a new wave of repression. Media employees who criticize Alexander Lukashenko's regime are arrested, beaten or forced to pay fines. The government is blocking access to independent media on the Internet. It also blocked the pages of the news portal Charter 97, which served as a platform for those seeking to promote democracy in Belarus.  In June this year, the Belarusian Parliament approved an amendment to the Media Act. The pretext was to combat disinformation, but it just means more new censorship. We must stand up for freedom of speech, independent media and democracy in Belarus. Arrests and physical attacks on journalists are unacceptable, just as censorship is unacceptable. Freedom of assembly and other freedoms should be our condition for cooperation with Belarus.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – President, intimidation, arrests and censorship. It ranks Wit-Russia a paltry 155th place on the World Press Freedom Index. As Europe's last dictator, Lukashenko keeps the media firmly in his grip, still after 24 years, and he does not tolerate critical journalism. So too in the aftermath of the peaceful mass protests that erupted in February 2017. 700 people were imprisoned, 100 of whom were journalists and the harassment of independent media continues to this day. Let's not be naïve. Lukashenko is not interested in reform. The rapprochement he seeks with the West is linked to his greed for more money, more power, more recognition. He just chooses eggs for his money. Lukashenko understands only plain language. As long as freedom of the press is not respected, there can be no rapprochement.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, in my speech in this House in April last year on the violent repression of the opposition march of 25 March, I said that freedom was not an expensive word to president Lukashenko's regime. Unfortunately this finding is now more true than ever. The assaults, seizures, arrests and prosecutions against journalists, independent editors and bloggers and the blocking of news sites, such as the renowned Charter 97, are a real attack on press freedom, democratic values that for us Europeans are so expensive and have become a modus operandi of an authoritarian regime that does everything to silence critical voices. But the truth is that nothing should surprise us from a regime that governs the only European country that still prides itself on having the death penalty as a visiting poster and which, contrary to what is happening across Europe, it teefully persists in the construction of the Ostrovets nuclear power plant. I believe that, for all this, that the European Union must continue to condition the standardisation of its relations with Belarus to respect for human rights, including freedom of expression, and this House, which in 2004 awarded the Sakharov Prize to the Belarus Journalists' Association, must categorically condemn the imposition of gags on the free voices of civil society.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to condemn in the most harsh way the practices of the Lukashenko government, which suppress freedom, suppress a plurality of views, of course freedom of the press, as we are discussing here. I would like to stress that we sometimes deal here with cases that happen very far from us, perhaps in other civilisational circles, and we often just forget such blatant violations of the fundamental values on which the European Union stands and which are happening right in our neighbourhood. I think that we should, in particular, deal with cases that are actually happening both in the European Union area and, of course, in our immediate neighbourhood. I don't want to underestimate the role of even the remote cases we're dealing with.  Media freedom is indeed a key value of democracy, and I would like to support the media concerned and the freedom of the media in belarus in general, not only with this language, but also with my vote shortly afterwards.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, I quote, ‘If we're supposed to become the nails in the coffin of a tyrant, I'd like to become one of those nails’. These are the words of Oleg Sentsov, the Ukrainian film director jailed in Siberia, but they fully apply in their scope to the work of Charter 97 and other independent journalists in Belarus. They have become uncomfortable nails for the political establishment. The EU made the first sign of goodwill towards Belarus in 2016. It’s now time to firmly remind the Belarusian authorities to make good on their promise to move forward on human rights issues. One sign of positive development from the Belarusian side would be to unblock Charter 97, end the intimidation of independent media and journalists, drop the fabricated charges and move towards the enabling of an independent media environment. This is all part of the international and regional human rights instruments adopted by Belarus. Failure to respect these commitments should result in the EU’s resolute action in Belarus.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: – Mr President, as we all know, Belarus is a 21st century dictatorship, nestled in Europe, and just as there is repression and threats to citizens defending freedoms and human rights in Belarus, there is also repression and threats to the media that they want to report freely on what is happening in that European country.  There is a saying, Mr. President, who says that God creates them and they come together, and dictator Lukashenko, curiously, is close friends with another dictator—Maduro, in Venezuela—and follows the same guidelines as Maduro, in Venezuela, with the media: he arrests journalists, attacks the media and pursues them, like Letter 97.  The European institutions must act and warn Belarus that all red lines are passing, and that gravity must lead to sanctions being imposed on the government of dictator Lukashenko in Belarus.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, EU—Belarus relations continue to be driven by the policy of critical engagement on the EU side. As always, we remain very attentive to the human rights situation in that country. At the same time, we believe that progress in a variety of fields can be better achieved by means of enhanced cooperation.  In this context, EU—Belarus relations have come a long way over the last two or three years. We have witnessed the proactive participation of Belarus in the Eastern Partnership. Here we see, of course, the resumption of the EU—Belarus sectoral dialogues and the signature of the Mobility Partnership in October 2016. People—to—people contacts, including youth exchanges, are also developing through the EU programmes, such as Erasmus+ and Horizon 2020, as well as Belarus’ accession to the Bologna process. We are now close to finalising the joint Partnership Priorities – which will be the first document of this kind between the EU and Belarus – an important building block in our relations, setting the strategic frame for our cooperation in the coming years and in which human rights and freedom of media issues play an important role.  We have recently observed an increased willingness by the Belarusian authorities to engage constructively with the EU on the human rights dialogue, including during our last meeting on 17 July in Minsk. Our support for an involvement of civil society will remain an essential part of our policy. The extensive agenda of this dialogue covered also the concerns on the freelance journalists in Belarus and the lack of legislation in this field. However, this increased willingness for debate has unfortunately not yet led to measurable legislative improvements in the human rights situation, notably on the freedom of media. In response to the new draft law on the media, the EU used the opportunity of the human rights dialogue to reiterate again the importance of freedom of expression and independence of the media. We called for unrestricted access to the internet. We are very much aware that several independent media organisations are working hard to achieve meaningful results in promoting critical thinking and democratic values, and we value their work very much. The EU at the highest political level has underlined to the Belarusian authorities that repressive actions against independent media, including the Charter 97 website, are contrary to the international commitments made by Belarus. We have equally called for the introduction without delay of a moratorium on the death penalty and the need to strengthen the independence of the judiciary. As we further pursue our policy of critical engagement, we will continue to follow closely developments in Belarus with regard to fundamental freedoms. The EU stands ready to assist Belarus in meeting its obligation in the area of democratisation and full respect for human rights. In addition, the EU will continue to provide financial support for civil society through the relevant EU programmes and initiatives. Steps taken by Belarus to respect fundamental freedoms, the rule of law and human rights will remain key for the shaping of EU policy towards Belarus. Let me also add one sentence. We are discussing today the human rights issues, but of course nuclear safety issues are also an overall EU concern. The EU is putting pressure for full transparency on the construction process of the new nuclear power plant in Ostrovets and we are also financing experts who are assisting in the new Belarusian national regulation on this.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – I close the debate. The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the United Arab Emirates, in particular the situation of human rights defender Ahmed Mansoor (2018/2862(RSP)).

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to talk to the United Arab States. Well, now it has been corrected, that was previously incorrectly displayed. Again, fundamental human rights are being violated in the United Arab Emirates. Government critics are arrested and sentenced to prison in unfair trials. According to Amnesty International, prisoners are being held in conditions equivalent to torture. However, accusations of torture are ignored by the authorities. In May, prominent human rights defender Ahmad Mansur was sentenced to 10 years in prison in Abu Dhabi, accusing him of crimes other than legitimate expressions of opinion. Because of his human rights work, Ahmad Mansur has been subject to repression for years. UN human rights experts are calling for his immediate release after his detention in March 2017. In addition to him, a number of other nonviolent political prisoners, including Dr. Mohammed al-Roken, are serving long prison sentences. In our resolution, we call for the immediate and unconditional release of Ahmad Mansur and all other detained non-violent political prisoners in the United Arab Emirates. I find it very strange that the conservative groups, the ECR and the EPP, do not want to support these fundamental human rights demands, and I therefore appeal to all Members to support the release of Ahmad Mansur and to vote clearly in favour of this resolution.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Sorry, it's actually a made-up. I would like to remind you: we are debating the United Arab Emirates, in particular the situation of human rights defender Ahmed Mansoor. Something else is displayed on the screens, but this is a mistake.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: author. – Mr President, the United Arab Emirates is a key ally of the European Union in the Arabian Gulf, but we ought to remind ourselves that, when the UAE cut ties with Qatar last year, the Emirati Attorney General warned that citizens expressing sympathy for Qatar could face heavy fines and prison sentences of up to 15 years. In this respect, this House must be crystal clear that freedom of expression and the respect of freedoms for individuals is not just a mere human rights issue. It is profoundly about lasting peace and prosperity in the region. Rule of law is essentially about protecting the citizen from the unjust acts of the government and the state, not the other way round. I can only, therefore, hope that, if the UAE complies with the United Nations Declaration on human rights defenders, we may then have a chance of seeing brotherly nations united again in promoting peace, security and prosperity in the Middle East.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, at a time when we see an increasing number of human rights defenders harassed for doing their legitimate work, we also see that the situation in the United Arab Emirates is extremely concerning. Human rights defender Ahmed Mansoor is in prison for allegedly publishing false information to damage the UAE’s reputation abroad. What is actually damaging the Emirates’ reputation abroad is the violation of the right to freedom of expression. We demand the immediate and unconditional release of Ahmed Mansoor and all other human rights defenders and prisoners of conscience. How can EU Member States continue trading arms and security equipment with UAE? How can the EU maintain its visa waiver programme with UAE when they clearly violate the human rights clause it is based on? I call on the EU to condemn the treatment of Mansoor and clearly and loudly call for his release. I say again that the EU must uphold human rights clauses in our international agreements and trade policies.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, the ambitions of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) seem endless. They praise themselves as young and high tech, and a country that has realised extraordinary growth. It hosts many international conferences and seeks a more active role on the global stage. Reputation is key for the UAE and I’m convinced that the arrest of Ahmed Mansoor, over tweets he sent, and the way he has been treated since, have not helped at all in this respect.  But of course we’re not here to give the UAE any PR advice. We are here to condemn human rights violations when they occur. Mr Mansoor has been recognised as a courageous human rights defender. He was the winner of the Martin Ennals Award and served as an adviser to Human Rights Watch. He is now in solitary confinement in secret detention. He is not allowed to contact family, has not been able to appoint an independent lawyer and has seen his passport revoked. Around USD 1 million have been invested in an Israeli-made digital surveillance system to track Mr Mansoor and his communications. I believe that it is essential that such systems, that are also made in Europe, are not exported to authorities that violate human rights and that we set a new high standard in updating our own export control rules. In the case of Mr Mansoor, we see his actions as falling within the rights to freedom of expression and call on the UAE authorities to release him. We also urge a review of the federal law combating cybercrimes to ensure that it is actually in line with international standards. I think it is essential that High Representative Mogherini also speak out, in unequivocal terms, about the case of Ahmed Mansoor, including during the next human rights dialogue with the Gulf States. To anyone in Europe considering a holiday in the UAE, it is important to know what can happen after you send a tweet or when you ask for democratic elections. I find it hardly an invitation.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, it has been a long time since we have been able to put the issue of human rights on the agenda in the United Arab Emirates. In this house, the Gulf countries have many friends, and this is especially true for the UAE, the only country in the region to benefit from visa liberalisation.  The UAE is one of the countries in the world that accepts the most immigrants. For example, Dubai has only 5% emirati. There are a few examples of "Westerns" working in multinationals (including young people who are discriminated against here, despite their degrees, and welcomed there with golden bridges), but the majority are workers hired for great pharaonic work and servants - mostly women - victims of the Kafala system, which makes them modern-day slaves.  But, as we know, the UAE is a good customer. France and Germany, as well as Israel, have provided them with spying software to monitor their citizens, including human rights defenders such as Ahmed Mansour, Ossama Al-Najjar and Nasser Bin Ghaith.  Worse, France is one of their main suppliers of weapons via a system of corruption that has recently been revealed by the French media. These weapons are being used in Yemen, in defiance of the Arms Trade Treaty and with the known humanitarian crisis.  So, yes, we must urgently put in place an arms embargo, demand that the Emiratis respect their international commitments and release all prisoners of conscience, and we must demand that our States also respect their commitments.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Mr President, I think that the European People's Party has always been on the side of those who are persecuted in the world. That is why we were not far removed from the case of Ahmad Mansour, a human rights campaigner who has been convicted of defamation, misinformation and public order violations, things that we in the European Union are certainly not following.  Ahmad has been sentenced to 10 years in prison, and I agree that there needs to be a dialogue with the government there about whether this decision violates the rule of law. Unfortunately, however, we are not satisfied, as the European People's Party, are with the final text of this resolution. Instead of sticking to the facts, we've listed a lot of ideological and nonsensical things that you can disprove in five minutes of studying the whole case on Google. I think that, as the European Parliament, we should be more credible and really try to stick to facts in our resolutions, not to the ideas and ideological phrases.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the human rights situation continues to deteriorate in the Gulf. The EU and its Member States must therefore take a serious stand against attacks perpetrated against human rights defenders by all our partners. The arrest and sentencing of Ahmed Mansoor earlier this year was already of great concern. Unfortunately, our fears have been confirmed by reports of ill-treatment that he was subjected to whilst in detention. This is not unusual. Information suggesting he has had no access to his family or to legal counsel has also been reported.  The United Arab Emirates (UAE) government must immediately and unconditionally release Ahmed Mansoor and drop all charges against him. He is a political prisoner who has been detained solely for expressing his views on social media.  Discriminations against women also continue to be part of daily life in UAE. There are severe restrictions in their freedom of movement, as women are still dependent on male guardians. As in many places in the Gulf, women’s rights defenders are unfairly attacked, harassed and prevented from conducting peaceful human rights activities.  The situation of labour rights is also very problematic, with widespread abusive practices by employers.  The EU must continue to demand significant progress on human rights in the Emirates. As European governments and companies continue to conduct billions worth of trade and investment, we have all the more responsibility to demand that the highest human rights standards be upheld.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr. President, in 2015 Ahmed Mansur already denounced the arrest by the authorities of the United Arab Emirates of detaining people critical of the Government. They made them disappear for months, used sexual violence and torture to obtain confessions, and condemned them in trials without any guarantees. Today, for his complaints and social media posts, this human rights defender is imprisoned and tortured. Human rights violations in this so-called European Union-allied country are rarely addressed. A country where the most basic rights are violated under the umbrella of the fight against terrorism; where the authorities arbitrarily restrict freedom of expression and criminalize peaceful criticism of politicians or state officials; a place where cyber surveillance weapons and technologies provided by European companies are being used to carry out this crackdown. Without our weapons, much of the repression there would not be possible. Mansur himself was spied on with these programs. In fact, he argues that the cause of much of the violence in the region is despair. And extremism grows when hope for peaceful change fades. We cannot continue to drive this hopelessness. We must demand the freedom of political prisoners, the immediate cessation of torture, as well as a real embargo on weapons and surveillance equipment, because we cannot be complicit in the acts of repression and torture committed in the United Arab Emirates. Beyond statements, you have to take sides. We have to do an arms embargo.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the last free voice of the United Arab Emirates has also been silenced. Ahmed Mansoor was the last remaining activist in the Emirates who dared to publicly criticise the authorities, paying for this serious affront with a ten-year prison sentence.  Can we still tolerate this attitude on the part of the United Arab Emirates towards human rights and towards those who also dare to name them? On the other hand, I wonder what we can expect from a country that ranks 116th in the human freedom index and where those who express sympathy for Qatar risk up to fifteen years in prison.  In a champion country for the limitation of fundamental rights, particular mention should be made of the anti-terrorism law, which contains a broad and deliberately vague definition of the crime and gives the authorities broad powers to prosecute dissidents and activists. I therefore believe that we must call on the Member States to ensure that surveillance instruments do not arrive in the Emirates from the Old Continent, which are then systematically used to monitor political opponents. Finally, I would urge the High Representative to take a clear and firm position on the Mansoor case and demand its immediate and unconditional release.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, some Muslim states, unlike our countries, have understood the mortal danger of the Muslim Brotherhood to freedoms.
