The UAE, along with other countries, has classified the organization as a terrorist organization. They show lucidity and protect their population, while the West is often blinded by the double language and seduction of the Brothers. Since 2011, the UAE has been the victim of manipulation and interference by Qatar, which uses the Muslim Brotherhood for this purpose.M. Mansour is, consciously or not, an agent of this conspiracy. He is affiliated with the Muslim Brotherhood and participates in the Gulf Center for Human Rights, an organization funded largely by Mr. Soros, master of the alliance of finance, crime and terrorism to destabilize our states and states. Ladies and gentlemen, we must absolutely support the UAE in its fight against terrorism, it is in our interest. I would add that the king had granted his pardon to this offender and that we are dealing with a repeat offender.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, Ahmed Mansoor has become a symbol of the ongoing crackdown on freedom of expression and association in the UAE. He has been harassed and persecuted by the Emirati authorities for many years since his first arrest in 2011, when he openly called for political reforms in the country. Last May, Ahmed was sentenced to 10 years in prison for expressing his views on Twitter. The UAE is trying to project an image of openness and modernism as part of its Vision 2021 Agenda. Dissenting voices are silenced through repressive laws, and human rights defenders have no space to carry out their legitimate activities without fear of retaliation. The Emirates’ poor record on fundamental freedoms was remarked on by the UN Commissioner on Human Rights in his periodical review only a few months ago.  We urge the UAE Government to free Ahmed Mansoor immediately and bring its legislation in line with international human rights standards. We would expect nothing less from a country that is part of the UN Human Rights Council.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, we’ve already heard about the human rights defender, Ahmed Mansoor, who has been incarcerated for ten years because he exercised his right to express his views online. Mansoor’s only crime was peacefully promoting freedom of expression and strengthening the role of the MPs in his country. Not only did he face repeated death threats, physical assaults and detention, but he has been denied access to a lawyer, his visitation rights have been suspended and he has allegedly been subjected to torture. The ruling highlights an unabashed and blatant use of over—the—top state security to target human rights defenders in the UAE.  Many Emirati and other activists face repression, arbitrary arrests and abductions by security authorities, who are unaccountable for their actions. So my question to the Commission is: what has the EU done to address forced disappearances while negotiating the recent Cooperation Agreement with the UAE? Secondly, Ahmed Mansoor has filed a Supreme Court appeal against his sentence. How can the EU ensure a timely and fair appeal trial? Thirdly, the UAE’s repressive cybercrime law was amended this week, introducing harsher penalties and sanctions. Will the Commission raise this issue and that of the electronic surveillance of human rights activists in its annual counterterrorism dialogue?

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Ahmed Mansoor was, until last May, one of the last openly critical voices of human rights violations in the United Arab Emirates that was still at large. After years of assault and death threats, he was arbitrarily detained in March 2017 and now sentenced to ten years in prison and a heavy penalty. The crime of this eminent activist who, in a peaceful way, claimed on social networks respect for human rights and the principles of the rule of law, including the possibility of holding elections by direct universal suffrage, is called, in fact, exercise of freedom of expression and not an attempt to disrupt the social harmony and unity of the country, as it intends to accuse the regime. The European Union cannot therefore fail to strongly condemn the arrest of Ahmed Mansoor, to demand the immediate and unconditional release of ahmed mansoor and to demand the immediate and unconditional release of him and all other political prisoners of conscience and to urge the Federation of the Seven Emirates to fulfil its international human rights obligations, including the abolition of torture and the death penalty, and to implement constitutional reforms ensuring respect for individual freedoms and an effective separation of powers.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá gaol tábhachtach againn le AEA agus tá dul chun cinn an-mhaith á dhéanamh acu maidir le cúrsaí geilleagair agus mar sin de. Ach, ag an am céanna, ní maith an rud é nach bhfuil saoirse ag chuile dhuine sa tír agus is eiseamláir é Ahmed Mansoor den chás seo. Tá sé i bpríosún toisc gur nocht sé a smaointe go hoscailte sna meáin sóisialta. Níor aontaigh sé leis an rialtas agus ní raibh an rialtas sásta agus anois tá sé i bpríosún le fada gan a phas aige agus rudaí mar sin. Dá bhrí sin, is ceart go bpléifimis a chás anseo ar maidin, go gcuirfimis brú ar AEA é a ligean saor, agus daoine nach é chomh maith, i dtreo is - má tá dul chun cinn á dhéanamh acu ó thaobh cúrsaí eacnamaíochta agus mar sin de - go mbeadh saoirsí bunúsacha ag chuile dhuine agus, go háirithe, Ahmed Mansoor.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, in the United Arab Emirates, as in the other countries of the Arabian Peninsula, there is not even the concept of democracy, because there is complete repression of human rights there. Activists are tortured, bloggers are persecuted, there are travel restrictions for dissidents. Discrimination against women continues in the United Arab Emirates and any labour rights are not respected, and the death penalty continues to exist. I therefore think that the European Union must send a decisive signal to the United Arab Emirates, which is involved in the massacre taking place in Yemen and in which European arms companies are selling arms. I believe that concrete measures should be taken towards the United Arab Emirates, no longer caressing them by the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are finally able to talk about Ahmed Mansoor, a well-known Emirati blogger, until more than a year ago the only independent voice, not yet in prison, to denounce the many human rights violations in the Emirates. Mansoor was sentenced to ten years in prison for posting false information on social media and promoting sectarianism and hatred. In fact, it seems to us that he has only peacefully exercised his rights in a country which, I would remind you, sits on the United Nations Human Rights Council, however absurd it may seem, but what is most surprising in this situation is, as always, our attitude as a Union, which is quite ambiguous and hypocritical. On the one hand, we call ourselves champions par excellence of the protection of human rights, on the other hand, we continue undaunted to provide spy software to regimes with dubious democracy that will use them to persecute and silence all critical voices. We are calling loudly for the immediate and unconditional release of Mansoor and all other prisoners of conscience. The EU must take a strong and clear stand when it comes to human rights, we must suspend export licences for technology and surveillance and arms to these countries, we can no longer be silent accomplices, giving priority to profits at the expense of people.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I want to stand up for Mr Ahmad Mansura and call for his release, but I cannot leave without a reaction one statement from our colleague, Mr Schaffhauser, who was the only one in this plenary to say that Mr Mansour should remain in prison. I consider this statement to be most outrageous. Mr Schaffhauser is therefore no longer sitting here, but I think it is truly outrageous for a Member of Parliament to express himself in this way.  For me, it is important to say here that the situation in the Gulf is generally deteriorating in terms of human rights violations, and we cannot remain silent even in the case of the United Arab Emirates. If Mr. Mansour is imprisoned in conditions that are similar to torture, he has no contact with a lawyer, I think that at this point we must raise our voice. Of course, it is a matter of choosing the specific wording of the motion for a resolution. I, too, am not satisfied with certain sentences here, but I would like to ask that Mr Mansúr be released.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is clear to me that freedom of expression is one of the achievements, particularly in the European Union. Nevertheless, we have a debate on Brexit, on the free movement of people. I believe that we also have very competent politicians in the United Arab Emirates. In many of the discussions we have had there, we have seen that there are also many in politics who want to live with our European values and who appreciate what Europe offers its citizens accordingly. That is why I believe that we should strengthen cooperation, above all with the Schura Council, so that, when we travel to the United Arab Emirates and, of course, here at the seat of the European Parliament, we can offer these fundamental issues of freedom of expression, including freedom of journalism, as an enrichment for the whole culture. From our practical experience, we have learned that the best way to talk to each other is to talk to each other.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the United Arab Emirates (UAE) was the first Gulf country with which the EU started a comprehensive dialogue on human rights, with the most recent eighth meeting taking place at beginning of July in Abu Dhabi. Since the first meeting in 2013, we have addressed several areas of concern and have seen improvements, for example, with regard to gender issues and religious tolerance.  Nevertheless, of course, concerns remain in a number of areas: freedom of expression and association, the right to a fair trial, and the situation of human rights defenders, including individual cases, are among the points we have raised consistently during our dialogue. We continue to advocate a cooperative and transparent engagement in which the EU can support the UAE in its endeavours to fulfil its international human rights commitments. As a first concrete step, we have been insisting on the need for enhanced information exchange. Despite challenges, there is no alternative to continued engagement in this domain.  In the EU, through our delegation in Abu Dhabi, we actively follow the overall human rights situation in the country, including individual cases. The case of Ahmed Mansoor is one case we have been actively following. Mr Mansoor, who was awarded the Martin Ennals Award for Human Rights Defenders in 2015, was sentenced in May this year to ten years’ imprisonment on charges related to the publication of false information and the spreading of hatred and sectarianism. We are regularly seeking clarification from the Emirati authorities on his situation, his whereabouts and his health, as well as details on the judicial process and the appeal procedure. In doing so, we have constantly reiterated the EU’s principled position on human rights defenders and on freedom of expressions, in line with existing EU guidelines.  Let me also assure you that we will remain actively engaged in this individual case. We will also continue to raise the general human rights situation with the Emirati institutions. We are of course aware of countries’ concerns over their stability and security, but we are quite convinced that one cannot have long-term stability without respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – The Belarusian media is faced with numerous challenges brought about by repressive and restrictive laws. In recent years, the nation has seen a deterioration of media freedom, notably targeting independent journalists and news outlets. In 2017, 100 journalists were arrested or detained, many of whom were covering opposition protests or reporting on issues considered unfavourable to the presidential administration. In recent months, new restrictions have led to increasing arrests, surveillance, libels, and fines against journalists. These National Media Laws create a system of extreme government censorship that directly contradicts the fundamental freedoms protected by the Belarusian constitution. Access to Charter97.org, a news site calling for democracy and pro-human rights, was arbitrarily blocked by the Ministry of Information, displaying an excessive restriction on the right to freedom of expression. Furthermore, in August, two independent news outlets were raided by Belarusian authorities, leading to the arrests of nine journalists. It is actions like this that have resulted in Belarus being placed at 155 out of 180 countries in the Reporters Without Borders World Press Freedom Index. Belarusian authorities need to strengthen respect for democratic principles and the right for truthful and unbiased journalism to prevent the climate for independent media from worsening.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the mass arbitrary detention of Uighurs and Kazakhs in the Xinjiang-Uighur Autonomous Region (2018/2863(RSP)).

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which is a very important one. China's Communist leadership is establishing an extreme police state in Xinjiang, detaining hundreds of thousands, if not more than a million, Chinese citizens of Uighur and Kazakh nationality. The reason given is that terror must be combated. I say that anyone who thinks that they can fight terror through general repression is really only making sure that there is enough water in which the terrorists can swim as fish. If you want to fight terrorism, you have to look at the experience of South Tyrol or the experience of Northern Ireland. I find it remarkable that, while China is gaining strength as a country, the Communist Party of China feels so weak that it does not even respect its own laws and respects religious freedom to its own citizens. I find it remarkable that China's leaders, while promoting the Chinese dream, are suppressing the current dreams of their citizens, at least if they do not want to dream in step with the BATon of the Communist Party of China. I think it is bad that China is also exporting this oppression. That is why we are opposed to it. Finally, I would like to recall the name of Ilham Tohti, a scientist of Uighur nationality who has long been in a Chinese prison for having exercised his freedom of expression. We will also remember him again and again.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Author. Mr President, I can fully imagine that foreign journalists are very undesirable in Xinjiang these days. Because the Chinese party state is testing the surveillance society in this western region with the indigenous people of Uighurs as human pawns extras. Yet from time to time, Western correspondents manage to paint a poignant mood picture of Xinjiang. For example, a Uighur replies to the question whether "security" can sometimes mean insecurity for the people there: "Yes, I have fear", is his answer. Because more than 100 family members, neighbours and acquaintances "study", i.e. have been staying in re-education camps for more than a year. And passers-by, Chinese officials are currently making mandatory "friendly visits" to Uighur families who are already on forced overnight stays. With this cruel anti-religious assimilation policy, Beijing is drawing world attention to a certain pivot in its ambitious belt and road initiative. Talk about pure anti-propaganda, self-harm.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. – Mr President, concentration camps are back. There are no other words to describe what is happening in Xinjiang. On paper, the ongoing Chinese ‘strike hard’ campaign in Xinjiang aims to eradicate terrorist threats. In reality, it is used to justify massive abuses, including the establishment of re-education camps or ‘education through labour’ camps. We are talking about up to a million people arbitrarily detained in camps and exposed to torture, forced indoctrination and collective punishment without, of course, the right to due process. Therefore, the answer is simple: these people are guilty of not being Han Chinese.  Colleagues, what else do we have to witness before taking concrete actions – gas chambers? Mass executions? China has no boundaries on its gross human rights violations, simply because nobody dares to enforce such boundaries. Therefore, in light of the overwhelming evidence of grave abuses in Xinjiang, I call on the European Union to take appropriate measure that match the gravity of the situation. In this respect, targeted sanctions against Party Secretary Chen Quanguo can no longer be delayed.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which China has undergone an astonishing economic development in recent years and decades. Unfortunately, however, this progress in the economic field has not been accompanied by progress in human rights and personal freedom. On the contrary, we are nottaking significant setbacks here. This Parliament has often dealt with human rights violations in China and has also adopted resolutions on them. Today, seven political groups are presenting a resolution on human rights violations in Xinjiang Province. What we hear from there is hard to believe: a million people in so-called re-education camps, people's total control over modern technological systems and the harassment of Uighurs living abroad. We call on the Chinese side to put an end to these practices. We are told that there are reasons for security, there is terrorism and separatism. Any state can, of course, guarantee public order, but excessive and collective action against minorities and religious communities is unacceptable. China is also losing a lot of credibility in the world. We see that Germany and Sweden have begun to stop deporting Uighurs and Kazakhs because they run the risk of having serious disadvantages there. We call on other states to do the same. We too say that the EU must address these human rights violations at the highest level – after all, all the leaders of our Member States are going to China. This must not be treated shyly and conservatively, so to speak. So, this resolution has met with great support here in Parliament, and I hope that the Chinese side will respond to it.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: author. – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, sadly Muslim ethnic minorities of Uyghurs and Kazakhs in Xinjiang, China, are subject to arbitrary detention, torture, restrictions on religious practice and culture. Nothing can justify the arbitrary detention and forced disappearance of one million human beings. Innocent people, mothers, fathers, brothers, sisters and friends have all disappeared. Where are all those people? What is happening inside the so—called re—education camps? Children are reportedly being separated from their families. We cannot be silent as human rights violations are committed on such a massive scale. I call for the immediate release of all those who are held in arbitrary detention in the internment camps and of arbitrarily detained political prisoners, such as Ilham Tohti. Starting from this resolution, there is a need for more concrete action. We need answers. We need an independent investigation in the region.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: Author. – Mr President, the resolution, based on allegations, unconfirmed data or information from entities as partial as the Executive Committee of the US Congress, aligns with the strategy of the United States and the European Union and its main powers of affront to countries that defend and assert their sovereignty, the right to development and independence. A resolution that takes the form of those who unacceptably refuse to intervene, to ingest themselves in third countries, a hypocritical resolution of those who fly out of human rights defenders, manipulate and trample on them in the aggressions and wars they promote, particularly in the Middle East and North Africa, laundering, feeding and instrumentalizing the terrorist hordes they cynically claim to fight. The European Union and this Parliament have no legitimacy to lecture on human rights. China's economic and social development and its projection and role in international economic and political relations make it the main strategic target of imperialism. That is the real reason for this resolution and debate.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: author. – Mr President, as an introduction, let me greet amongst us on the balcony Mr Dolkun Isa, the President of the World Uyghur Congress and a tireless fighter for his people. Welcome amongst us.  (Applause) Mr President, I would like to thank the European On the twelfth of September, the EP report on the state of EU-China relations was adopted by a large majority in the European Parliament. The document emphasises that the comprehensive strategic partnership between the two parties is based on principles such as the rule of law, human rights and democracy and aims to strengthen mutual trust and understanding between the two parties. In this sense, I speak out against the mass and arbitrary detention of more than one million Uighurs and Kazakhs in re-education camps in xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region. The Chinese communist state cynically continues to deny the existence of these modern concentration camps. Every single member of the Uighur community of 10 million people, which is also an independent people, is closely monitored, trampling on the basic human and community, ethnic and religious rights entresed in the Chinese Constitution. I call on the Chinese authorities to put an immediate and unconditional end to the policy of destroying the identity of Uighurs. A genuine strategic partnership and mutual trust can only be said if china guarantees the fundamental rights of all its citizens, including minorities, and respects its human dignity. Let us act united against China. Our economic interests in the strategic partnership must not be an obstacle to honest dialogue and the uttering of our legitimate human rights requirements.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, China has nothing to fear from its minorities, because the Han nation is the biggest in the world. Therefore, it’s most illogical and outrageous to see the Uyghur minority – only 11 million – subjected to systematic oppression, which, in practice, deprives them of their national culture, identity and religion. Up to one million Uyghurs are supposedly being treated in the centres of indoctrination.  Therefore, we call on the Beijing government to immediately end the practice of mass arbitrary detentions for members of the Uyghur and Kazakh minorities. We call specifically on the Commission and EU Member States’ governments to raise systematically the issue of human rights violations in the Xinjiang Province at the highest level, and we ask EU Member States’ governments to prevent harassment of the Uyghur and Kazakh diaspora in EU countries, especially as regards preventing them from being returned to China against their will.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Group of the Party of European Democrats, we are unfortunately talking about repeated and confirmed circumstances, denounced not only by the best international journalism, but also by leading figures in the European Commission, and we are increasingly denouncing in this House the very serious violations of what are then human rights. The inhabitants of Xi'an are subject to daily police checks, facial recognition procedures and mass telephone tapping, the existence of mass detention camps has now been established, and the objective is obvious, the erasure of the identity of the Uyghur minority. And we know, because for a long time, the risks they run are well known, China still applies the death penalty, its anti-terrorism law defines this vaguely, often allowing for precisely arbitrary application of the law. The European Union must act as a bulwark in defence of the rights of minorities, and therefore also of these rights, of the rights of the Uyghurs, and urge third countries to give careful consideration to requests for international protection, including those of other minorities such as those in the Khazar region.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, thoughts are free. Who can stop them? The beginning verse of one of the oldest German protest songs against oppression of the liberty. The Chinese leaders should know that thoughts cannot be forced upon them and yet it is just that what they are trying to do in the Xinjiang region with their witch-hunt for all that is not Chinese. Uighurs and Kazakhs are being locked up en masse and arbitrarily in political re-education camps. They are brainwashed until they are cured of their ideological disease and their thoughts are purified. Even outside the walls of the camps, people are intimidated, isolated, spied on. Behind the China that is opening up to the world lies a ruthless state apparatus. Despite the many agreements and dialogues and meetings, the country still dangles at the bottom of the Human Freedom Index. The EU has a duty to ask the Chinese authorities in clear language to stop persecution, to release the prisoners, to close the camps. Because, Mr President, the thoughts are free and no government can prevent that.

name: Urmas PAET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, lately the focus of the international community has tended to fade away from the human rights violations in China for certain pragmatic reasons, but a country wishing to be an economic superpower should not be allowed to violate the rights of its people. According to the UN, up to one million Uyghurs are being held in detention camps without any access to legal process. Their family members don’t know where they are, or whether they are alive at all. Collection of DNA samples, GPS tracking systems being installed in vehicles and cell phones, cameras installed in their homes – these are just some of the examples of how they are being harassed. The Chinese Government must release all those held arbitrarily in those detention camps and release the names, whereabouts and status of those that have disappeared. China must stop the systematic repression and uphold the commitments it has made by adhering to international human rights treaties, and the EU must address this issue in its meetings with the Chinese Government at all levels.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 'no one used to say a single word, they remained silent as mutes, they were afraid to accidentally say something wrong', are the words of terror of Sayragul Sauytbay, a former Chinese propaganda teacher in one of those re-education centres, aka concentration camps hidden in the mountains of western China, the Xi'an, where about a million Uyghurs , Kazakhs and other minorities are now arbitrarily detained. This figure is not even certain because there are not even public records of prisoners. Unfortunately, however, these structures exist only too well, as do the numerous violations of the human rights of minorities, including the forced disappearances of political dissidents, just like Ilam Tohti, and the intimidation of the diaspora in our Member States too, even relatives of refugees abroad, who are harassed by the Chinese authorities in order to bring them back and thus punish their rebellion. We have a legal and moral obligation to demand the immediate release of all prisoners in these illegal centres, which must be dismantled. Europe cannot and must not bow to the shameful logic of business as usual with China.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the province of Xinjiang, where I visited some 20 years ago, has long been the scene of an armed separatist movement, which has carried out numerous attacks and is fuelled by militant Islamism. Under these conditions, which state would not monitor extremist mosques or extremists? That's what China does.  But those who talk about concentration camps with two million detainees, as a member of the UN Committee for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination in Geneva on 13 August 2018 did, without any evidence of this information, are making a fool of themselves. Two million, or a million, as I have heard here, is the population or half of the population of Paris. Yet this is where the myth of mass arbitrary detention comes from. This is fake news that you should fight instead of validating it by your resolution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, we are here today concerning the deterioration in the protection of human rights by the Chinese authorities, in particular with regard to the rights of ethnic minorities. I strongly condemn the arbitrary detention of Uyghurs and other minorities, as well as the mass surveillance of their daily lives through the collection and use of data which they cannot object to. Such issues must be raised by the EU with the Chinese authorities at every political level, in order to reflect a strong, unified voice in its approach to China and to prevent a further deterioration of the situation. I call for the immediate release of those detained arbitrarily. The fundamental rights to freedom of expression and religion, in addition to the right to peaceful assembly and association, must be reinstated and firmly protected. The promotion of, and respect for, universal human rights, democracy and the rule of law is at the core of the longstanding relationship between the EU and China. The EU’s commitment to upholding these values and China’s expressed interest in adhering to them require a strong condemnation of the situation in Xinjiang province.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I am very sorry because I saw that Mr Polčák was reporting to the blue card, but it was up to the previous speaker, as I understand it, so we will not go back to that anymore. Sorry, I didn't notice.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: – Mr President, I welcome this resolution on the mass arbitrary detention of Uyghurs and Kazakhs in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region. I also want to salute Mr Dolkun Isa, President of the World Uyghur Congress. Respect for universal human rights, democracy and the rule of law should remain at the centre of relations between the EU and China.  This resolution condemns the increasingly suppressive regime that minorities, in particular Uyghurs and Kazakhs, face in China today. We call on the Chinese Government immediately to end the practice of mass arbitrary detentions, and to close all the camps in which one million people are arbitrarily imprisoned. An independent investigation mission should be allowed to visit Xinjiang and Tibet. Our resolution also calls on the Chinese Government immediately to release Uyghur scholar Ilham Tohti, and all other detainees. Dear colleagues, China is a big country. It is also rich in ethnic and cultural minorities, from Tibetans to Uyghurs. It should not be scared of them. It should recognise and respect them. This would make China an even greater country. Free Uyghurs, free Tibet, free China.

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Mr President, China is a critically important international player, and its significance will only increase in the coming decades. Being such an important actor and a member of the Security Council brings with it certain responsibilities. Whilst flawed, the current international system has brought with it increasing security and prosperity for citizens around the globe. But far too many countries do not respect human rights. For such an important player to show such blatant disregard only erodes the efforts that have been made globally.  Whilst we can all understand and sympathise with the fight against radical Islamic terrorism, Chinese actions in Xinjiang appear to have crossed the line. Dealing with terrorist groups must not slip into the general persecution of the people of Xinjiang. China must decide what kind of future we are all going to share. The application of basic human rights must be amongst them.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, grave human rights concerns have long been common in China. Recent developments, however, show a turn towards the worst. Emboldened by the silence of Western democracies, China has been stepping up its efforts against religious minorities and ethnic groups it deems unreliable, such as Uyghurs, Tibetans, and Kazakhs. Some of the most significant and disturbing developments currently happen in the Uyghur Autonomous Region, with the massive—scale development of re—education camps. Human Rights Watch has rightly compared these re—education camps to black holes to which people are added and from which they do not get out. This is why it is so difficult to estimate how many thousands of people have already been sucked into them now. What we know is that today nearly every family in the Uyghur diaspora has a missing relative or loved one. If it is to prove effective, the EU—China Human Rights Dialogue cannot avoid thoroughly investigating such issues.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The situation of the Uighur and Kazakh minorities in the northwestern Chinese province of Xinjiang is rightly referred to by researchers as cultural genocide. As part of this effort, Uighur adults are placed in re-education camps and their children are separated from their families and placed in orphanages. The goal is one – to destroy their national identity. The scale of the phenomenon is perfectly illustrated by the level of investment: in 2017 alone, the Chinese government allocated $30 million to build 45 new orphanages for 5,000 children. The scale of the use of technology to scrutinise the lives of ethnic minorities, as pointed out in a recent human rights watch report, is also appalling. I therefore believe that the Chinese Government should be strongly demanding the immediate closure of the camps, the release of the wrongly detained persons and the cessation of violations of the rights of ethnic minorities. It is also important to ensure the free access of journalists and international observers to monitor the situation in the province.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I wanted to respond once again to the comments made by Mr Schaffhauser, who once again made a very outrageous statement, because he actually denied any pressure from the Chinese Government on the Uighur minority. I must say that he has behaved in exactly the same way as Mr Lopes of the United Left, who has denied parliament's legitimacy to comment on these issues at all. It shows that, in fact, the starting points of some radical members of the far left and right are unfortunately the same, and perhaps they should sit next to each other, and not like this through the hall. I would really like to stand up for the rights of this minority, because their oppression undoubtedly has ethnic origin, and it is clear that China is merely masking its alleged fight against terrorism. We should also stand up for this minority on our visits to China, as My colleague Paet said, because we can speak and we should not just remain silent in our delegations.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, if any other country detained one million people in camps and forced 11 million people to live in a repressive police state, we would be calling for a referral to the ICC on the grounds of ethnic cleansing. At the very least, sanctions would be imposed. Yet, most governments have declined to criticise Beijing or even ask for more transparency about the situation in Xinjiang out of fear of economic retaliation from China.  This Parliament has always been at the forefront in defending human rights worldwide. Sadly, this time our resolution does not represent a breakthrough, but merely an expression of concern. Therefore, I urge you and the Parliament to take all measures necessary to persuade the Chinese government to close the camps and end all human rights violations in Xinjiang against the Uyghur people.  The EU must stand ready to adopt targeted sanctions against all responsible for the persecution of Uyghur, victims of 21st century concentration camps. It is our obligation to acknowledge the Uyghur’s existence as a global community and act now in order to prevent the world’s next disaster.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, the inhuman treatment of Uyghur and Kazakh minorities in China has been taking place without adequate attention from the international community for too long. Hundreds of thousands of people from these Muslim minorities have been detained in camps under horrible conditions, including torture and restriction of their religious practice and culture, with a view to re—educating them out of their religious beliefs. It is still hard to believe that such camps can exist in the 21st century.  Uyghurs and Kazakhs must have the right to freely choose their way of life and propagate their traditions, culture and beliefs while staying in China. Therefore, I call on the European Union to bring up this issue and demand the closure of those camps in all future political dialogues and negotiations with China as a matter of primary importance.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is already becoming the norm that every time china is addressed in this House is rarely for good reasons. If we do the accounts of the number of statements, resolutions and motions that this Parliament has made about the violation of human rights, freedom of worship, freedom of expression and arbitrary judicial proceedings and against the democratic rules practiced by the Chinese Republic during the reign of the Chinese President, we would easily come to the conclusion that China is one of the world champions of oppression and authoritarianism , side by side with Putin's Russia and Nicolas Maduro's Venezuela. The truth is that since Xi Jinping came to power in 2003, the human rights situation in China has deteriorated further as the Chinese government intensifies its hostility to peaceful opposition, freedoms of expression and religion and the rule of law. Ladies and gentlemen, in the face of so much evidence and recent reports that Uighurs, Kazakhs and other ethnic minorities, mostly Muslim, in the Autonomous Uighur region of Xinjiang have been subject ed to arbitrary arrests and torture and severe restrictions on religious and cultural practices, the Union must energetically demand and condemn these practices and pressure the Chinese Government to put an end to its punitive activities and actions.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, as has already been said, the situation in the Uighur Autonomous Region is more than alarming. Up to one million people are held in re-education facilities. I dare say that this is how Xinjiang is the largest prison in the world. The main accusations against them are often very vague as support for terrorism. The Xinjiang case exemplary to see how the fight against terrorism can be exploited against the population, and we should know that there is an update on the fact that on October 1, mass movements of Uighurs in closed wagons with blinded windows from south to north were recorded. This method of mass transfer of prisoners is reminiscent of the time of Stalinism in the Soviet Union and its repression.  I therefore fully support the European Parliament's call on China to put an end to this repressive treatment of Uighurs, and I agree that the EU should also consider targeted sanctions against those responsible for these repressions.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Mr. Chairman, I welcome this Resolution, which is an expression of our concerns about the human rights situation in China.  Human rights should be the focus of Relations between the European Union and China. In any case, Uighurs and Kazakhs should be released and I condemn the situation that is happening with foreign journalists. They are not allowed to report from these concentration camps. I mean, if it were another country, about a million people being held captive, we would all be very worried, but when it comes to China, then it is not very much the focus and therefore it is good that the European Parliament is considering this Resolution and that in this way we express our dissatisfaction with the human rights situation in China.  Anyway, I applaud the resolution and hope it contributes a little bit to freeing those poor people.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the EU is closely following the situation in Xinjiang. We are deeply concerned about credible reports pointing to a serious deterioration of the human rights situation there. In addition, the recent concluding observation of the EU Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination merits close attention. This expresses alarm about reports of mass detention, political re—education camps affecting Uyghurs and other minorities, mass surveillance, travel restrictions, and Uyghurs abroad being returned to China involuntarily.  These findings present serious grounds for concern. The EU calls on China to engage constructively with the Committee recommendations. We have received accounts from EU citizens of Uyghur origin in the EU, who report being pressurised to return to China or to provide information about their relatives there. Travel documents of family members in China have reportedly been confiscated or not issued to prevent people from leaving. There are legitimate concerns about the security of Uyghurs and other people belonging to minorities if returned to China.  The EU urges all countries to consider carefully requests for international protection from such people and, where applicable, to ensure respect of the non—refoulement principle. The EU repeatedly raised this concern with the authorities during the last EU—China Human Rights Dialogue in July 2018. The situation in Xinjiang, freedom of religion and belief, and the rights of persons belonging to minorities, especially Tibetans and Uyghurs, were addressed. The EU reiterated its request for a fact—finding visit to Xinjiang, including access to the camps and the need to implement recommendations from international human rights bodies. The EU supports the request made by the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights for her office to have access to all regions of the country. Respect for fundamental human rights requires that all human rights, including freedom of expression, freedom of religion or belief, freedom of movement, assembly and association, the right to due process and the right to non—discrimination, are respected in Xinjiang, as they should be anywhere in the country, in line with China’s international obligations and national legislation. The upcoming Universal Periodic Review provides an opportunity for open dialogue between China and its international partners on the full range of human rights issues.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I would like to apologise very much to the Commissioner for the behaviour of my colleagues. Well, sometimes it's easier to make high-flying statements than to keep elementary rules of politeness. I close the debate. We move on to voting. (The meeting was suspended pending a vote)

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am asking for the floor to denounce a disgusting event that took place this morning in Italy. This morning, a newspaper published this headline: 'Cholera returns to Naples, migrants bring it'.  So this is totally false news and the title is a disgusting headline. We are rightly fighting against fake news on social media, but this Parliament must also fight against those newspapers that foment hatred and foment racism on our continent. This title is a disgrace! This news is a disgrace!

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I wanted to invoke Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure. During the debate on neo-fascist violence, President Paşcu spoke to me after half a minute, halfway through my speaking time, and did not return it to me because I criticised his party colleague. If President Paşcu is unable to remain neutral, he should not hold deliberations.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Thank you, that is noted. The next item is the vote.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, we have removed the barriers to the free flow of data within the European Union. The fact that we are establishing the fifth freedom within the internal market is a game changer for the European digital economy. I would like to say it’s a good example of a Europe that delivers and I want to thank all of you warmly for great cooperation and support.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, I wish to insert the following after paragraph 3: ‘Condemns the launch of Iranian—built ballistic missiles by the Houthis against targets in Saudi Arabia, including civilian areas, and their indiscriminate use of sea mines and internationally banned anti—personnel landmines.’

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, rigged auctions, conflicts of interest result in losses of more than EUR 2 billion per year. All this money is from the pockets of European citizens. There are also fake public procurements, because that's what we're talking about in this report. The digitisation of the public procurement system has delayed. It is only since July that all Member States have to use digital platforms for public procurement. Platforms must detect fraudulent practices and corruption, and Member States must also implement electronic forms as soon as possible.  The Commission must ensure that national contract registers are connected to the European register. Electronic public procurement is more transparent, reduces red tape, simplifies and shortens processes, ensures the correct spending of money.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Honourable Madam President, honourable Members, I voted in favour of my Colleague Kuelho's report on the package of measures relating to the public procurement strategy.  The Commission adopted its last package of similar measures in 2014, with a number of Member States finding it difficult to implement the measures in their national laws within the time frame set, and against as many as four of them, the Commission initiated a criminal procedure for non-application of the rules. This shows that it is time for new measures that take into account the administrative specificities of each Member State of the European Union, but also have clear and flexible implementation systems. This package of measures provides Member States with the possibility to modernise public procurement. I supported the report because the main recommendations it makes are to improve the transparency of contracts and bids by increasing online publishing, improving access for small and medium-sized enterprises to public procurement contracts. I believe that they are all at the heart of a good functioning of the public procurement system and the spending of funds appropriately with visible and useful results for citizens of countries.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, I would like to welcome my colleague Carlos Coelho for his brilliant work on the public procurement strategy and to highlight that the spending of a considerable amount of taxpayers' money must comply with ethical values, transparency and integrity in order to efficiently provide quality goods and services to citizens.  According to the Commission, 55 % of procurement procedures still use the lowest price as the sole award criterion, without weighing any social, economic sustainability or environmental protection criteria in these decisions. The seriousness of the hiring processes requires that amateurism and empirical management of acquisitions by public entities be put to an end.  Finally, after four years, after the revision of the four legislation, the Commission calls for the modernisation and simplification of procurement systems using e-governance technologies and the use of economies of scale, with joint cross-border procurement, making full use of the European single market. However, I cannot fail to mention the consequences of irresponsible public management, as was the case with public-private road partnerships in Portugal, which have harmed and harmed the State by millions of euros. I greet the civil society organisations that have been able in my country to denounce these situations and try to obtain due justice. For the good of taxpayers, I hope that Member States will be able to welcome this report and use it to operate the necessary change in public management.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Dear Colleagues, public procurement plays a very important role in the construction of social and physical infrastructure in each country. I share the criticism that with nearly 55% of public procurement in the European Union, the most important criterion for choice is the "lowest price" factor. This creates conditions for unfair or unfair competition from larger and solvent players. Local representatives suffer most often from this. The lack of quality also accompanies the phenomenon "lowest price", as unfortunately it was evident from the incident in Svoge in Bulgaria, in which 18 people died. There are abuses and inflated prices in the implementation of a number of public procurements in my country, such as "School Fruit" and "School Milk". It's time for this to stop. I support the report on measures relating to the public procurement strategy because I believe that procedures need to be made more transparent, more traceable through the introduction of e-services by the end of 2018 at the latest and for offenders and their custodians to be swiftly and proportionately punished.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, drug trafficking, trafficking in human beings, terrorism, cybercrime are committed across borders by groups operating in several states. Eurojust therefore has a key role to play in genuine cooperation and coordination between the judicial authorities of the Member States and also in supporting investigations involving third countries. The new regulation must increase Europol's efficiency and clarify the boundaries between Europol and the European Public Prosecutor's Office, designed to ensure good cooperation between the two.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I welcome the support and the steps being taken to secure criminal justice cooperation across the EU and I thank my colleague, Axel Voss, for his good work, as always. As criminals continue to use more and more sophisticated methods, so too must our criminal justice actors, and to this end, I’m encouraged by the reinforcement of Eurojust’s role in fighting transnational crime. Should crimes such as terrorism, cybercrime, human trafficking and money laundering, continue to rise across our borders, it will be essential that Eurojust can exchange more information with Member States and provide sufficient data protection. I support the introduction of a new executive board, which will enable increased efficiency for Eurojust, and plans for regular reporting to European and national parliaments. These efforts will be increasingly important to my constituents in Ireland and constituents right across the European Union, so I am very glad to see this progress in the EU’s criminal justice cooperation.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, I voted for this regulation because it maintains the balance between access to non-personal data in the public or private sector and issues related to national security in certain areas of the public sector. The Regulation removes barriers to access to information, for example: unjustified restrictions imposed by public authorities in the Member States on the location of data - these are signs of protectionism that have no place in the single market; also uncertainties about the law applicable to cross-border data processing or changing service providers, such as the cloud, in the event of their abusive practices. That is why we are taking an important step towards opening up the market to new business models and innovation opportunities.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Today we voted on a document on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a framework for the free movement of non-personal data in the European Union. This is undoubtedly an important issue, given the increasing digitisation of the economy. The agreed text introduces a rule allowing the posting and processing of non-personal data anywhere in the European Union without unjustified restrictions.  The exception to this rule, which I believe is crucial, is for reasons of public security, which has been included in the document, which is why, like other members of my group, I supported the final text.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Madam President, in the modern world of new technologies, and given the speed at which they enter our daily lives, we must ensure that information is used wisely and in a way that does not jeopardise the processes at which it is used. I support proposals to prohibit data localisation requirements, except where there are overriding public security reasons. The free flow of data within the European Union will play an important role in the development and innovation of innovation and will play a significant role in achieving data-based growth and innovation. Member States' public authorities and structures will benefit from greater freedom of choice for data service providers, more competitive prices and more efficient provision of services to citizens. For this reason, I supported the report.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I had the pleasure of attending and taking part in the debate on this topic last night. I commend Anna Maria Corazza Bildt on her good work and agree with her that this is a game changer. I very much welcome the significant step to protect the free flow of data, removing any unjustified national laws that limit data storage to that Member State. I welcome the exemption for restrictions for reasons of public security and the harmonisation of this regulation with the GDPR, of which I was a rapporteur.  The removal of technical, legislative and economic barriers to data flow between cloud services will be a great advantage for SMEs across the European Union. This will encourage competition in the data storage market and will prove particularly helpful for organisations looking to store and process data in different Member States considering the challenges posed when trying to change service provider.  The Irish economy will benefit significantly from the removal of unjustified data localisation restrictions so I am happy to be voting in favour of this report. It’s a good job and will help especially when you go to the internet of things and connected cars in due course.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, perhaps the fundamental problem with global human rights today is that the national legislative system has not kept up with the challenges of the global economy. Many companies carry out corporate responsibility activities voluntarily, and that is, say, part of reputation management, but as long as corporate responsibility is based only on voluntaryity, there will be companies that go where the fence is lowest and costs the lowest possible, then take advantage of a false competitive advantage that could put people's lives, health or environment at risk. It is good that corporate responsibility lives on many levels. The main objective of today's close vote was the UN Agreement on International Enterprises and Human Rights. Europe must, of course, lead by example and lead the process in order to reach such an international agreement. Thank you to the majority of meps who voted for this! In anticipation of an international agreement or a European framework, a #ykkösketjuun campaign has been launched in my country, Finland, to pursue national legislation, the Corporate Responsibility Act, which would oblige companies to find out what impact its activities have on the realisation of human rights.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, today we have adopted in this Parliament a resolution which represents a historic step, a resolution in which we call for something urgent, and we do so more explicitly than ever before: for the European Union to lead in the United Nations the creation of a treaty that obliges us to respect human rights to businesses, namely transnational ones.  From now on, every time the Delegation of the European Union or one of its Member States at the United Nations hinders progress towards the treaty, every time they put buts to human rights, we will remind them that today, 4 October, the European Parliament has made it clear: voluntary corporate responsibility initiatives do not work, we must go further and create legislation and there must be sanctions for those who do not comply. There are no more buts that are worth it.  I am also addressing the Member States. The European Parliament, that is, the representatives who have chosen your citizenship, are asking you to support the treaty. If you don't, you'll be failing this same citizenship because you're not representing it. Spain, as a member of the Human Rights Council, has an opportunity to make a difference. I therefore hope that the Government of Pedro Sánchez will be actively involved in Geneva, that it has a voice of its own to defend the treaty and that it will not hide behind the delegation of the European Union, as the Government of the PP did.  And I want to thank the Social Democratic Group for its seamless support.  Finally, I address those who voted against them, who have been left alone today because they do not want to support human rights. Have you asked your voters what they think of a treaty like this? Please, if even the Holy See supports it!  Despite having been seeing what you are voting on for four years now, I still believe in common sense, I still believe in people, in everything — also in which you vote for you - and I know that today you would be on the side of human rights.  Today it is a triumph of the world's vulnerable.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, under eyes that no longer want to see the world's most serious humanitarian crisis unfold in Yemen. name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Madam President, the humanitarian emergency situation in Yemen is unsustainable. Three-quarters of Yemen's population — twenty million people – are at risk of death from malnutrition. And this is not the first resolution we have adopted in the European Parliament on Yemen, but the situation remains the same. Because in the end the paper is just paper. name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to explain why I supported the resolution on the situation in Yemen, even though the left blocked the oral amendment by my colleague Tannock, who wanted to mention the Iranian shelling of targets in Saudi Arabia.  This resolution of ours calculates the facts about the tragic conflict, its terrible humanitarian consequences and the suffering of the civilian population. name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There are many Christians living in this war-torn country.
