name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the major question for a written answer, with debate by Karin Kadenbach, Georges Bach, Catherine Bearder, Dominique Bilde, Richard Corbett, Miriam Dalli, Isabella De Monte, Jorn Dohrmann, Pascal Durand, Stefan Eck, Eleonora Evi, John Flack, Jacqueline Foster, Eugen Freund, Arne Gericke, Michela Giuffrida, Karoline Graswander-Hainz, Jytte Guteland, Martin Häusling, Anja Hazekamp, Maria Heubuch, John Jude Kirton-Darling, Jeppe Kofod, Zdzislaw Krasnodabski, Jean Lambert, Jo Leinen, Arne Lietz, Edouard Martin, Alex Mayer, Ana Miranda, Marlene Mizzi, Maria Noichl, Younous Omarjee, Massimo Paolucci, Sirpa Pietikäinen, Pavel Poc, Evelyn Regner, Pirkko Ruohon Lerner, Davor 'krlec, Bart Staes, Keith Taylor, Thomas Waitz and Josef Weidenholzer to the Commission: Animal welfare, use of antibiotics and the environmental impact of industrial broiler farming (O-000095/2018 - B8-0410/2018) (2018/2858(RSP)) ).

name: Pavel POC
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner, the current industrial broiler farming is the prevailing model of supplying the European market with quantities of relatively cheap meat. So-called professional farms with more than 5,000 broilers now cover 90% of the total broiler population in Europe. But the global expansion of intensive poultry farming is not just a question of animal welfare, it is a question of human health. Broiers typically breed tens of thousands of pieces in one space without daylight access, without any enrichment of the environment, without any possibility of meeting the normal needs of those animals. Problems of the musculoskeletal system, dermatitis, deformation, pain, stress, inability to manifest natural behavior are just examples of problems that these animals face during their lives from transport to slaughter. Indeed, it is literally appalling what we, as residents of 21st-century developed countries, tolerate as normal economic practice. If the public knew where the animals were, I believe most people wouldn't be willing to eat meat at all. Over the past 80 years, broiler life spans have decreased to an average of 49 days, while increasing their slaughter weight by 100%. Can you even imagine? Since hatching at 2.7 kilos in less than two months? But these experiments with nature are already out of the hands of producers, and that should interest even those who are not interested in animal welfare. The poor health of broilers in industrial farms is forced by the preventive use of antibiotics in order to prevent epidemics and the spread of diseases. According to statistics, around 70% of all antibiotics in the EU are used in agricultural livestock production, especially in large farms, and most of it is used for bulk feed or water medication. This method of using antibiotics then leads to the emergence of resistant and multidrust-resistant pathogenic strains. Some strains of Campylobacter, Salmonella and Escherichia are now showing this resistance, and more are being added. If we don't start addressing this global problem in time, we risk trouble with our own health care system. We have no effective substitute for conventional antibiotics, and the loss of this tool would push our health system literally back a hundred years. The fact that poultry farms are, among other things, a major source of ammonia pollution looks like a mere trap alongside the problem of antibiotic resistance. I believe that we should carefully assess the impacts of large-scale production and promote more sustainable farming methods, and in this context we would like the Commission to answer the following questions: Will the Commission take measures to improve the enforcement of the Broiler Directive, in particular as regards the systematic and consistent use of animal-oriented indicators? What measures does the Commission intend to take to promote alternative chicken production systems – such as those that choose more suitable breeds, lower stocking intensity, enriched environment, access to daylight, etc. – given that such systems can help reduce ammonia emissions and reduce the need for non-critical use of antimicrobials and improve animal welfare? When will the Commission publish a report on the socio-economic impacts of mandatory labelling methods?

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mrs Bie-kowska, we are very much looking forward to your reply.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I took this point on behalf of Commissioner Andriukaitis, but I have to tell you that I am personally very interested in the subject too. I am very concerned about animal welfare and so I am happy to be here with you.  The EU is a major global producer, as was said, of broilers. The poultry sector employees over a quarter of a million people in Europe, with 23 000 large broiler farms in Europe. But of course for us the most important thing for now is discussing animal welfare, and bird welfare.  Over the years, there has been good work in this House on that issue, and I thank you very much for this. The European Union has developed a range of legislation, which is leading the world on animal welfare. Our farmers, in each of the 28 Member States, put this legislation into force almost every day. We take animal welfare very seriously and remain fully committed to constant improvement through the life of the directive and other legislation. We work closely with the Member States to ensure that the legislation is fully enforced. This includes the directive on the protection of broilers, the Broiler Directive. Since coming into force in 2010, the Broiler Directive has provided a legal framework to the Member States, which has considerably improved the management and housing of broilers. This in turn has improved the welfare of the birds.  The Broiler Directive was the first piece of EU legislation to introduce animal—based indicators as a way to monitor the welfare of animals. Current information and research shows that the use of these indicators, such as footpad dermatitis in poultry, has brought about the majority of improvements in farm welfare for chickens. Encouraged by this, we will continue to develop animal—based indicators as a way of continually improving conditions for animals. We believe that there is still a lot of room for improvement in animal welfare, but the work already carried out by the European Union gives us hope that a lot has also been achieved so far. In 2019, the Commission, together with the Member States and stakeholders, will work to identify further animal—based indicators for broilers. We hope that these new indicators can be used by national authorities and also by the Commission to better target their action and thus improve the implementation of the directive. Investment in the health and welfare of animals on farms, of course, brings additional benefits. As has just been mentioned, improvements in animal husbandry have reduced the need to use medication on farms, including antibiotics. This is very significant and provides a strong boost to our fight against antimicrobial resistance. Through the marketing standards for poultry meat regulation, we provide incentives and support for animal—welfare—friendly chicken production. We list certain specific terms, which can only be used for poultry meat produced in alternative production systems. These include terms such as ‘extensive indoor’, ‘traditional free range’ and ‘total freedom free range’, which are defined and limited to farms meeting specific criteria. Member States may additionally co—finance investment in animal—welfare—friendly production systems through the Rural Development Programmes. This funding can be used, for example, to upgrade, fit and improve housing where it goes beyond the minimum required standards. As regards the question of mandatory labelling of poultry meat, the Commission carried out a feasibility study on animal welfare labelling, following extensive stakeholder consultation, and the outcome of this study was included in a report from the Commission to the European Parliament and the Council, adopted at the end of 2009. This study concluded that mandatory animal welfare labelling in respect of minimum EU standards would offer no added value. Our work to improve animal welfare standards and implementation in the EU continues. In 2019, work will commence on the designation of the EU Reference Centre for Animal Welfare for poultry, rabbits and fur animals. This centre is expected to provide scientific and technical information, through which we will be able to support Member States in the implementation of animal welfare rules. I look forward to the discussion and your views on this.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, on 13 September we also adopted the report by Mrs Kadenbach on the European Commission's proposal for the European Single Health Action Plan against resistance to microbial agents. At the time I had the opportunity to say what I now repeat: it has become indeferred to halt the unruly use of antibiotics introduced by the intensification of animal husbandbreeding practices. Commissioner, even if we can accept that antibiotics are important in ensuring food security, we cannot, however, let the evolution of breeding technologies that aim to reduce costs and achieve maximum income in livestock production take place at the expense of the future of our health.  The truth is that high-density farming uses antibiotics improperly and systematically on the farm of poultry, often in unhealthy environments, to prevent the spread of diseases resulting from the conditions of steniguity, confinement and stress in which animals are kept. These conditions still have the aggravation of inhibiting the natural immune system of animals, but the use of antibiotics such as prophylaxis and metaphylaxis in food-producing animals will see its ambitious end this year with the final approval of the report on the regulation on the use of veterinary medicinal products.  In this regulation it will also be very clear that the disease should be avoided not by routine antimicrobial use, but by good practices or techniques of compartmentalization hygiene and good animal management.  I believe that protecting consumers and public health involves using healthy, good quality breeding animals with adequate genetic diversity and growing naturally is to ensure breeding conditions that respect the behavioural needs of species such as social interactions and hierarchies and also to maintain an animal density that does not increase the risk of disease transmissions. Commissioner, I now ask the question that is implicit in my colleagues' oral question: can Member States count on the implementation of the measures necessary to have quality food products on the market, without unnecessary antibiotics that prevent the emergence of antimicrobial resistance and, I will like, Madam President, with the last question: can European citizens consume poultry meat without concern?

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which is We are talking today about intensive broiler farming. When you see the advertising about chicken meat, it is advertising that stands for a new way of life. It's all about light cuisine, it's about modern cuisine, low-calorie cuisine. It is also about the feeling that you have to buy an honest product here. But nowhere are reality and advertising as diverging as in the chicken sector. If people knew how this supposedly lightweight product is produced, they would refrain from doing so. In other words, the advertising that sells us chicken meat as light and modern in Europe has nothing to do with reality. I would like to ask you, Commissioner, whether you are doing everything in your power to bring these two things together? Because thoughts that people have in mind when you think of chicken meat, and reality? Because chicken meat is not healthy, as it is produced – neither for the chickens nor for the people. The issue of antibiotics has been raised several times. Healthy, although it is often read in the magazines, chicken meat cannot be so in this mode of production. Can it be easy? It may be easy to buy chicken meat, but the life of the animals is not easy. The life of the animals is often without sufficient space, without water, without ventilation in an ammonia tank, in an ammonia cloud, for which people usually have to put on a gas mask, because they do not really endure this ammonia cloud. So it's not easy! And the next thing: Is it honest? We stand for honest transparency in Europe, which should definitely support customers in their purchasing behaviour. And it's not honest! We urgently need better labelling to make it clear which product the buyer buys when he goes to a shop. For this we need labelling, for this we need more honesty in transport, more honesty in slaughter, more honesty in the selection of breeds – two-way breeds would have existed for a long time or slower growing breeds that honestly had something to do with the product. Commissioner, you have a great deal of responsibility. And in the word responsibility is the word answer. Ask your Commission to answer these questions! Take action when it comes to chicken fattening in Europe, because chicken fattening in Europe is still a smudge corner. We urgently need to clarify this.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Writing a directive is probably easier than enforcing the rules, although the biggest problem seems to be automated, factory-like, huge, dozen thousand poultry farms, where it is difficult not only to maintain bird welfare conditions, but above all to ensure healthy meat of farmed chickens.  First, poultry rearing in small flocks similar to natural ones was reduced, then mulching on litter was eliminated, replacing it with rearing in single-level cages up to eight storeys in order to achieve high production without taking into account the natural needs of birds. At the moment, European law allows a density limit of 33 kg/m2, sometimes even more, which means that one chicken has an area less than a sheet of A4. Therefore, it is not only necessary to ensure lower stocking density, access to natural light, better air quality or reduced ammonia emissions. All this should reduce the need for antimicrobials.  The most important, however, would be measures to reduce the negative impact of poultry meat consumption on public health, reducing the bioaccumulation of substances such as herbicides, pesticides and, of course, antibiotics. It is also about minimizing fetor and noise from farms. Is it genetically modified or does it contain pesticides? A huge threat – already spoken here – is, of course, the bioaccumulation of antibiotics in chicken organisms and the possible getting into water and wastewater. There is also a lack of noise and fetor regulations, which exposes local residents to inhalation of odours with exposure to respiratory diseases. There is also no regulation of the discharge of faeces into groundwater, which results in an increased content of nitrates, nitrites, which have a carcinogenic effect on the gastrointestinal tract.

name: Tilly METZ
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Here are three arguments to show why urgent action is needed. First, it is a breeding that is completely contrary to the welfare of the chickens. Spaces are overcrowded and chickens cannot move enough, tingle, hop on branches and not even properly spread their wings. This treatment causes enormous suffering. Their bones become fragile and their behavior abnormal.  Second, it has consequences for the health of animals and human beings. Most chickens in the European Union are kept in intensive breeding systems that contribute to poor health conditions and require mass treatment with antibiotics to prevent or contain epidemics. This develops the emergence of antimicrobial resistance, which is a threat to public health. Third, it has serious consequences for the environment. Intensive farming is also a source of pollution. To name but one: ammonia. Ammonia pollutes air, water and soil and, instead of subsidizing more environmentally, animal and human practices, we fund these large-scale exploitation practices by subsidizing them with the CAP.  The way we treat animals is a mirror of our European society and I am sure that we do not want a society where industrial farming and animal abuse continue to be subsidised. We can change that and I call on the Commission to do that, thank you.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, today is World Animal Day and it is the first time that the European Parliament has debated the welfare of chicks in the meat industry. Such a chicken grows in less than 6 weeks from a small chick to a kilo stunner of more than 2 kilos. They sink through their paws and they literally grow dead. In the Netherlands we call this chicken a flop chicken. 50 years ago, it took chicks almost half a year to reach the weight of an adult animal and now only 42 days. Their short life is a long agony. They are crippled, they suffer from foot ulcers, they have massive joint pain and heart failure. In order for as many chicks as possible to survive, an enormous amount of antibiotics are used, and only because in the European Union production and consumption must grow compulsively, at the expense of public health, at the expense of the environment and certainly at the expense of animals. We must put an end to this by banning fast-growing chicken breeds as soon as possible. In addition, chickens need space, fresh air, daylight and a free range so that they can go outside daily but certainly also in case of a barn fire. For the past 11 years, the European Commission has been idling. Her report showing that there are major welfare problems in the chickens came 6 years too late and did not give any solution. I am therefore counting on the support of my colleagues, but above all on the support of the European Commission to finally tackle this and to give animals the protection they deserve. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today on World Animal Day, I am pleased that we can debate this oral question in plenary, especially as we are focusing the light on those animals that are all too often forgotten and that deserve our full attention.  The problem today is serious and it is right to talk about it because there are more and more investigations and testimonies that give us the measure of how intensive broiler farming is a completely unsustainable business. Animals are fortuitously fed and grow structurally weak, for the sole purpose of producing low-quality meat sold at low prices. Animals kept in large numbers in extremely small spaces in terrifying conditions, where animal and zoonose diseases spread with extreme ease. Unfortunately, the recipes used by industrial livestock farming in these situations are completely wrong. Acting on chickens to prevent outbreaks of disease through the preventive and systematic use of antibiotics cannot be an adequate response, it cannot be because it only aggravates the phenomenon of antibiotic resistance, both in animals and in humans. This is now the most pressing public health emergency in Europe.  In this connection, I would like to point out, as has been said, that Parliament expressed itself in a report by Mrs Kadenbach in September. That is why I believe that the sector must be reminded of its responsibilities and that the processing of livestock farming is more necessary than ever in the European Union and in Italy in particular. My country is the second largest for the use of antibiotics on farms, with over 1 300 tonnes per year, an impressive figure, but it could be drastically reduced if we finally decided to make another model of meat production and consumption prevail, a model based on good farming practices and the application of strict biosecurity measures. But not only that, in order to reduce the use of medicines and the considerable environmental impact of industrial broiler farming – and we have mentioned ammonia emissions are a huge problem – the decision to abandon the use of cages can play an important role. That is why I am asking my fellow Members here to sign up to ice, the End the Cage Age initiative, and I ask the Commission to listen, to start listening to those many citizens who are already mobilising for this great battle of civilisation.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, crammed, repeatedly injured, unable to move or even for a moment the light of day, how many people across Europe are suffering from these unworthy living conditions to fill our plates with the 13 million tonnes of poultry meat produced annually in Europe? This macabre daily newspaper is not the exception since the percentage of farms with more than 5,000 head owns 93.5% of chickens in the European Union. These animals, themselves selected for their extraordinary growth, four times faster than that experienced in the 1950s, attest to the extreme industrialization of our agricultural production. Far from being the preserve of a horde of vegan bobos confided in its material comfort, as it is said in the media, the question of animal welfare conceals in it the fate of a world population in explosion. Indeed, at a time when antibiotic resistance threatens to precipitate us into an unprecedented health crisis, which would cause up to 10 million deaths per year by 2050, the impact on humans of their intensive use to compensate for the infections that abound in these overcrowded farms is now proven.  Finally, the ethical question remains, since if the treatment of the most vulnerable testifies to the degree of civilization of a human society, we can no longer ignore the abject suffering inflicted on so many sentient beings in the name of unbridled productivity. We don't have two hearts: one for animals and one for humans, wrote Alphonse de Lamartine. We have a heart or we don't.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, there may not be many MEPs here with our good Commissioner Bieńkowska, but we’re pretty unanimous in our approach to this topic – not surprisingly so, because the welfare of Europe’s animals is an extremely important issue and one that is often overlooked. The 2007 Directive lays down minimum standards for the protection of chickens kept for meat production. As always, it is key that enforcement of these directives is consistent across Member States and, up until this point, we have not seen that happen. Some of the problems we were speaking about today allegedly include the fact that chickens which are bred purely for the purpose of meat are often reared in groups of tens of thousands in terrible conditions, without any possibility of expressing natural behaviours, such as perching, pecking or even experiencing natural sunlight. There are also several knock—on effects to humans from rearing chickens in this way, such as a threat to our health from antibiotics used on chickens. This is simply an issue we can no longer ignore. Furthermore, it seems the pollution caused by industrial poultry production is ever—increasing and is now seen as a major contributor to ammonia pollution of air, soil and water. I believe the industry is currently taking steps to address some of these issues, but again it is imperative that a comprehensive approach is taken to ensure we tackle these problems in the most efficient way and spread awareness across all Member States of the extent and variety of the problem. I support Karin Kadenbach and others’ questions to the Commission and wonder what is going to be done to improve the welfare of broiler chickens. Are any steps being taken to address some of the issues? Are broiler chickens going to be afforded a better existence? Are there alternative methods of rearing chickens being looked into that can attempt to improve their quality of life, while also minimising the negative impact it has on humans and on the environment?  Finally, I would say that if we reared cattle and sheep in this way, I think the farms would be closed down overnight. Why do we treat poultry in such a terrible way? It’s not acceptable any longer.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Commissioner, I do not know who wrote your speech, but you said at the beginning that Europe would be a global player, a global exporter of chicken. Do you really think that it makes sense to maintain European production with genetically engineered soya from Brazil, which has been grown on land where primeval forest is being cut down, so that we can supply the world market with chicken? The ammonia remains here, the groundwater contamination remains here and the mass animal husbandry remains here. Do you really believe that this is a model for the future of European agriculture? You have argued with Jobs. You know, thousands of farms in Europe close every year because they can no longer keep up with the pricing of industrial agriculture. Do you not think that it would result in a lot more jobs to end this type of agricultural system and, in future, to support European farmers in keeping chickens in a way that is appropriate and environmentally friendly here in Europe? And if you do not want this because of animal welfare, if you do not care how the chickens suffer, then please do so at least in order to protect the health of Europeans. 25 000 deaths every year due to multi-resistant germs – I do not know what argument is needed to reconsider this type of agricultural policy! I would ask you, too, to influence your colleague Mr Hogan, to propose a support model here that favours European farmers and ends the promotion of the agricultural industry.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Huge quantities of antibiotics are still being used in chicken fattening, and a great deal of antibiotics will still have to be used in the future, because the animals that have been painted in these meat factories, which are only for profit, are so susceptible to disease, because the conditions of keeping are pitiful, so that they only reach their masts with antibiotics. In addition to broad-spectrum antibiotics, even reserve antibiotics are being used irresponsibly, which are used in human medicine as the very last resort in various diseases, because there are more and more strains of bacteria that have become resistant to antibiotics as a result of agricultural practice. The antibiotics used contaminate not only poultry meat, but also excrement and slaughterhouse waste, they contaminate our drinking water and soils. Do you really know what is happening, what a disaster is being done, that the Commission is courting the chicken barons with its policy? It is thus shoveling the grave for future generations who will die from these diseases, from multi-resistant diseases. Ten years ago, the administration of three units of antibiotics was enough to cure pneumonia within a few days, and today, old people die en masse in our hospitals from pneumonia bacteria because nothing helps anymore. That is your responsibility, ladies and gentlemen in the Commission. The fact that the Commission has acted and is acting so hesitantly is a disgrace, it is an abysmal scandal. That is why I say to you: I expect the Commission to act now, otherwise the animal rights activists will act!

name: France JAMET
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with regard to broilers and the use of antibiotics to promote the growth of animals, I would like to point out here, as I have repeatedly said in the INTA Committee, that while their use is prohibited in 51% of our Member States, it remains totally and 100% legal and widespread in the United States, Canada. , in all Mercosur countries, Australia and New Zealand - all countries affected by the free trade agreements negotiated by Mr Juncker and his Commission. Be aware that, as things stand, it is considered that these drug practices are not far from competing, or even exceeding in volume, medical prescriptions for human beings. We must already revisit the conditions of these trade treaties, and it is imperative and vital to put in place a real system of traceability and labelling of imported products for the welfare of animals, of course, and for information and consumer choice because it is also the health of our fellow citizens.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We are taking up an important issue here. Chicken is becoming increasingly popular. If you look at the data, in the last ten years alone, production in Europe has increased from eight million tonnes to thirteen million tonnes. We could also discuss whether it really makes sense for our diet that we in Europe, for example, eat more chicken each year than we eat apples. That, too, should perhaps be questioned a little. But we must not lump everything together. There are also situations in Europe where chicken is properly produced. In Germany, for example, there is the Animal Welfare Initiative. I myself was in the Netherlands with the Committee on Agriculture two years ago. Stables have been developed there together with the University of Wageningen, where animal welfare is very much taken into consideration. However, the Commission is not in a position – and I agree with the previous speakers – to implement Directive 43/2007, that is to say, to finally ensure that the rules that actually exist are implemented. Then those who do it right are ultimately the painted ones, because when they invest in animal welfare, they are ultimately no longer competitive, because others simply produce cheaper. We have also seen this in the production of eggs. It was and still is there. Those who invested in better stables were ultimately no longer competitive on the market because others in Europe continued to work with old stables. The same thing happens with the eggs. The stables in Europe have been dismantled and transferred to Ukraine, and the eggs have then been imported, duty-free. Here, too, we have to be careful. Either those who import have the same rules, or else they have to impose protective duties on these products. Anything else is unacceptable to our farmers.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I was a little more generous with speaking time today because I do not have any speeches on the catch-the-eye procedure. That is why I did not want to interrupt you all, especially since – which is rare enough – there is a fairly uniform opinion here in plenary.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members who took the floor. This is an important topic. Thank you very much for this short discussion on the issue. I will of course pass all of your remarks, concerns and the whole message to Commissioner Andriukaitis, but let me just point to two things.  First, the Commission wants to move things forward and to really work on this subject. We will continue to work on the enforcement of the directive, but at the same time – and that is why your remarks were so valuable – we need to work closer together to reduce the impact of industrial farming as far as possible, both for the welfare of the chickens and for the environment and human health. We will take all of your concerns into consideration. Let me also tell you, a little bit more personally, that I will do my best in my capacity to get a lot of interest in the Commission on this. This is what I can commit to you.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the October II part-session.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.
